name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday, 14 June 2018.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, this year marks the 100th anniversary of Nelson Mandela's birth. With his innate leadership skills and constant personal example, the South African President has embodied the principles of freedom, equality, justice and reconciliation like few others in the world. These values represent, taken as a whole, the very essence of the European Union and of this Parliament, which in 1988 awarded it the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought. It is a fair recognition of his long battle to end apartheid and his commitment to equal rights. The Republic of South Africa will organize a series of initiatives throughout the world to convey to young people the memory of this great personality of the twentieth century. The European Parliament will participate and contribute to this programme of celebrations. I would like to take this opportunity to inform you that next week we will be hosting a concert, in honour of Nelson Mandela, at the European Parliament's Yehudi Menuhin space in Brussels. This concert will be organized together with the South African mission.  At the September plenary session here in Strasbourg, I will receive Mrs Graça Machel, wife of former President Mandela. Mrs Machel has been committed for many years to women's and children's rights through the Graça Machel Trust, which aims, among other things, to enhance and convey the civil and moral legacy that Nelson Mandela has left us. I would also like to express, on behalf of Parliament, our deep concern at the reports of the repeated attacks on the Roma community in Ukraine in recent months, including the brutal stabbing of a 24-year-old man in an attack in which four other people were injured, including a woman and a ten-year-old boy. We express our sincere condolences to the victim's family and friends and wish a speedy recovery to all those who were injured. Relations between the European Union and Ukraine are based on common values and the Eu ropean Union attaches great importance to the rights of minorities. That is why we will continue to ask the Ukrainian representation for information on what is happening and on the development of the situation.

name: Antonio TAJANI

name: Ska KELLER
text: – Mr President, I actually have a point of order. Thank you, first, for your words on the Roma in Ukraine. Regarding the Council meeting that took place last week – and I’m sure we have different views on the outcome, and we are going to discuss that tomorrow – there is one point on which I think we should all stand united. Mr President, you, and all of us, have said how important it is that the Council takes a step forward on the reform of the Dublin Regulation, on which we have found a majority within this House. The Council conclusions say that they want to find a consensus on Dublin among themselves, which, first of all, means that it won’t happen and, secondly, means that they plan totally to ignore Parliament and to ignore co—legislation. This is something that we cannot let happen. We cannot let ourselves be ignored. I really hope, Mr President, that you can send a very strong and swift message to the Heads of State and Government that we will not be ignored as co-legislators. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mrs Keller, for your information, at the Council meeting, I spoke at length during my speech about the need to approve the Dublin reform and the whole package on the reform of the right of asylum. I believe that the need to approve this reform has been included in the final document precisely because I have put a great deal of emphasis on this issue and many Heads of State or Government have intervened, after my speech, to underline the importance of the work carried out by Parliament, which must already be seen as a starting point for opening the debate.  I do not therefore believe that a reform can be adopted unanimously – since the Treaty provides for it to be adopted unanimously, because the Treaty provides for it to be adopted by qualified majority, which I have said and repeated. I believe, however, objectively, that the inclusion in the conclusions, unlike what was in the initial draft, where no mention was made of the reform of the right of asylum and dublin, was achieved thanks to the action of the European Parliament. However, I will reiterate this position before the debate that will take place in this House, reminding President Tusk of Parliament's position, and I will also reiterate this at the meetings of these days: I would like to point out that I had already sent the letter before the Council. As has been confirmed by those present, there has never been such an intense debate since my report ten years ago, that is, since the President of Parliament was present at Council meetings. I therefore believe that the European Parliament's message has arrived loud and clear on this issue, as well as on all the other issues – I am thinking of the issue of own resources – agreed during the meetings with the Conference of Presidents and the Contact Group on the next Community budget. However, thank you for your support: I will continue to support and reiterate the European Parliament's position, I repeat, even before the debate with the Council begins, before President Tusk speaks.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, my point of hand is based on Article 24, Article 25, paragraphs 3 and 13, and Article 28 on the competence of the quaestors of the Parliamentary Office and the procedure to be followed. For the past 18 months, three-quarters of my allowances have been punctured to the tune of 300,000 euros. This absolutely considerable sum is supposed to represent the salaries and payroll taxes of one of my assistants, whom I say he worked entirely in accordance with his status. The decision was taken by the Secretary-General, without even being heard while the measures of application of the Statute, Article 68, paragraph 2, state: "any decision on recovery is taken (...) Member concerned having been heard beforehand." The European Charter of Fundamental Rights, Article 41, paragraphs 1 and 2, states that 'every person has the right to have his affairs dealt with fairly', which includes, among other things, the right of every person 'to be heard before an individual action that would adversely affect him is taken against him'. Article 6 of the European Convention on the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms goes in the same direction. The charter for good administration, which we voted for, explicitly states this. I am speaking to my colleagues and to you. Irrespective of the political differences between us, is it decent to allow such a situation to continue in an administration which I have seen, for 30 years now, the arbitrariness gradually developing at the expense of the rights of parliamentarians, without the quaestors and the Bureau in any way? Is it appropriate for a Member to find himself in my situation, which is also that of several people on these benches, without the Secretary-General, as a true concussionary, or the bodies of this Parliament, deigning to hear it?

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to inform you and this House that yesterday, for the fourth time, for the fourth year in a row, the city's Gay Pride demonstration was banned in Istanbul for the fourth year in a row. Two years ago, with my colleague Terry Reintke, we were there and we were immediately charged by the police, who also stopped us. But yesterday the mark was crossed, because rubber bullets were fired at the demonstrators to clear the demonstrators. I think it is intolerable to have relations with a country where Erdogan is achieving this degree of aggression towards the civic opposition: I call on this House to express solidarity with the demonstrators who were so mistreated yesterday and I call for a severe condemnation of this attitude of Erdogan, who can no longer stand any protest and has opponents, magistrates, trade unionists and any other opposition arrested in his country.  We can no longer tolerate it!

name: Maria ARENA
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Mr. President, indeed the Ebola epidemic in the Democratic Republic of Congo has been officially considered to have been stopped in recent days. The World Health Organization estimated four days ago that the epidemic was no longer occurring in the Democratic Republic of Congo. name: Charles GOERENS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, with all due respect to Mrs Arena, I cannot follow her in the conclusions she has just presented to you. Indeed, the European Parliament had entrusted me with a report on the Ebola crisis at the beginning of this Parliament. In 2014, I presented my conclusions, drawing attention in particular to the gaps in detection, the late consideration of this phenomenon, and the delayed response on the part of the World Health Organization. One of the things we had required research on a vaccine for production. The recommendation was followed by the facts. That is why this epidemic has not had the scale it had in Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone, but the discussion is still relevant and I will tell you why. If we broaden the debate, we risk losing sight of an important aspect. I believe that we need to assess what has been done and I believe that we can put to our credit having had an influence on the Commission and on the global health institutions. If the epidemic has not happened, so much the better, but that is not a reason to ban it from our discussion. Just because something no longer enters the 8 p.m. news doesn't mean we have to banish it from our speech. That is why I would like to keep the item on the agenda as proposed.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the Turkish elections on 24 June were a triumph for Erdogan, who was re-elected President with 53% of the vote. name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, in 1985, the first film in the Terminator series showed robots attacking human beings. name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the report by Françoise Grossetête, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Public Health and Energy, on research and energy, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the European defence industrial sector development programme, aimed at supporting the competitiveness and innovation capacity of the European defence industry (COM(2017)0294 - C8-0180/2017 - 2017/0125(COD)) (A8-0037/2018)

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this is a decisive step for Europe's defence which we will take by adopting this regulation tomorrow. This is the first community program for the defence industry. We've come a long way on this. What is possible today was unimaginable a few years ago.  I would therefore like to thank the European Commission and you, Mrs Bie-kowska, in particular, for your help along this legislative journey. Your involvement in effective European defence has been decisive. The Bulgarian Presidency has also played its full role in bringing the negotiations to a successful conclusion within the allotted time. Finally, thank you to my two fellow rapporteurs from the AFET, SEDE and BUDG committees, Ioan Paecu and Esteban Gonzalez Pons, as well as to the shadow rapporteurs of the ITRE committee with whom cooperation has been very productive. We have come up with a strong text to implement this programme as early as January 2019. Parliament has been heard, whereas this is an area in which Member States are not used to having a co-legislator. From the beginning, I have advocated a truly European approach to this programme, the only way to rapidly advance its implementation and reap all the benefits at European level. This new programme addresses three challenges for the European Union: budgetary efficiency, competitiveness and strategic autonomy. Budgetary efficiency, first of all, because it is no longer possible to continue to develop so many different defence technologies and products in Europe without cooperating and organising. Member States must be encouraged to invest together in future technologies and avoid duplication, based on their capacity priorities. At least three companies from three Member States will be required to submit action. It's pragmatism. Existing projects must be supported while encouraging further cooperation. Above all, it is urgent to have the same specifications between Member States to avoid any delay or additional cost. Competitiveness secondly, because the European Union must remain at the forefront to keep innovative industries on its territory and the thousands of jobs that depend on them. Our defence industry needs more Europe to provide less expensive, more reliable, more independent technology and thus showcase its technological wealth. Excellence must be the basis for the selection of companies in this program, whether large groups, mid-sized companies or SMEs. In fact, we have paid particular attention to SMEs that have a very useful capacity for innovation and adaptation in this sector. At least 10% of the budget will have to be reserved for them. Strategic autonomy at last. It is crucial to guaranteeing the European Union's freedom of action in the world and essential to dealing with the current instability of the international context. With this programme, a new dynamic is being set in place to encourage Member States to acquire technologies and products financed by EU money. What is our autonomy if we persist in buying hyperconnected products from third countries? Everyone must take responsibility for instiling a wind of independence in the European Union in this matter. We have also been able to reserve funding for companies based in the European Union with very limited exceptions for those that would not be controlled by Europeans. It is indeed crucial to avoid the leakage of our technological know-how. The role of our Parliament has been decisive in this regard. To succeed in this programme, Member States and industrialists must bring their best projects to European level. This is essential for this programme to create real leverage for defence investment in Europe. The new Post-2020 European Defence Fund already offers a prospect for this new defence industrial policy. This is an ambitious course. Ladies and gentlemen, our fellow citizens are calling for the European Union to protect them from new threats. This program is a concrete way to respond responsibly. That is why I ask you to support this inter-institutional agreement in tomorrow's vote.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. – Madam President, I would like to thank Ms Grossetête for her thanks. The European Defence Industrial Development Programme (EDIDP) is a pilot project which strategically supports the competitiveness, innovation and efficiency of our defence industry, consolidating our strategic autonomy, and tactically bridges the research-to-development gap in security and defence capabilities, thus providing EU added value in defence through more cooperation and better spending. It also provides a solid foundation for closer coordination with other regional and international frameworks, especially NATO, on capability development priorities. The EDIDP comes at a crucial time in international politics when both the political and military superstructures and their underlying basis in free trade are under attack. As expected, the EU is a ‘status quo’ power, in favour of maintaining the rules-based Old World order which, through peace and free trade, has provided for our security and prosperity. And the EDIDP, complementing all the other measures taken or envisaged in the field of security and defence, is a major tool helping the EU to do that.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: rapporteur of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Grosset-te, on an extraordinary job and the Commissioner, Mrs Bie-kowska, because she has also done a great job and has helped this Parliament to see the light.  From the point of view of the Committee on Budgets, I think it is a great success, because 40% of the funds will come from fresh money, it will come from the margins of the budget, so we will not have to cut – as was the case in the first project – neither the Galileo programme nor the Copernicus programme nor the Connecting Europe Facility. If Europe is of legal age, it has to know how to defend itself.  Last weekend, Donald Trump, our top ally, said Europe is as bad as China, but smaller: we would do very badly by letting our security exactly depend on Donald Trump.  That is precisely why—and knowing that NATO is there, and with all due respect, and without prejudice to NATO—let us begin to imagine that we may one day have to defend ourselves. Let us put a first brick so that this Europe has the capacity to defend the European model of life.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am very happy to see the outcome of our negotiations on the European Defence Industrial Development Programme. I think that while facing new and evolving threats the European Union must first, of course, ensure its strategic autonomy, must become a security provider, but at the same time we must make sure that the European defence industry remains innovative and remains competitive.  Today the EU defence market is, as we all know, fragmented. There are a lot of inefficiencies, there is a lot of duplication in the way that public money is spent. The European Defence Industrial Development Programme is one part of the European Defence Fund launched by the Commission in June last year.  We’ve prepared and we’ve been working on two windows of the Programme: the research and capability windows. The research window is already well on track with the pilot projects and the preparatory action. Together with our EDIDP they mark really a new era in European defence, the EDIDP with EUR 500 million for the last two years of this budgetary perspective.  So I would like to thank Parliament very much for its support for those two instruments because, as we all know, all three institutions made concessions to reach agreement. I also want very wholeheartedly to thank the two rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs; they were working very hard in order to reach their agreement at a really record pace. This was a huge effort for all of us and we all know it was not a very easy process.  For everyone, of course, there were some points that didn’t make it through the negotiations and that is why we have foreseen a number of declarations that will have to be appended in the record of tomorrow’s session. I mean especially the Commission’s declaration on the list of priorities for the adoption of the work programme, on the selection of experts for the evaluation of proposals, and on the intention of the Commission to manage directly the programme. Overall I certainly believe that the compromise is a very good and balanced text. It is balanced, inclusive again, and it will truly help the EU defence industry to cooperate more and more efficiently. I am pleased that the final outcome upheld most of the proposals from the Commission and, of course, even improved on some of them.  On a few specific points: the budget. The final agreement providing for 60% of the budget to come from redeployment of existing programmes and 40% from the margins is, I think, a good and, once again, balanced one. As these redeployments have not yet been earmarked for specific purposes, we are confident that this will not affect the good implementation of their respective programmes.  Additionally, the programme provides strict conditions for the participation of companies based in the EU but not under EU effective control, and for cooperation with companies from outside the EU. It also provides conditions to ensure that intellectual property rights and EU added value will remain within the European Union. We will also introduce conditions for subcontractors’ participation.  The European Defence Fund, as was said before, is not a protectionist tool; we just want to make sure through this programme that the security interests of the EU and the security interests of its Member States are preserved. A firm obligation not to fund actions related to products prohibited by international law was added and a specific reference has been made to defence products designed to carry out level strikes without human control.  On governance: the regulation provides a very well defined and framed list of categories of capabilities that the work programme should include. We will define the work programme, of course, with the limits of our competitors and, as I said before, the Commission intends to implement the programme directly.  Finally, as I stressed when presenting our proposal to you in October last year, the programme is not only – definitely not – for the big companies and for the big Member States. I am very happy to see that the inclusive character of the original proposal was not only maintained but even strengthened in the final proposal. The programme promotes the participation of small and medium-sized enterprises from different Member States in the defence supply chain and provides some bonuses for cross-border SMEs and cross-border mid-caps. It is open to participation by beneficiaries from all Member States.  Now, the most important thing is to be ready by January 2019. I hope that the work programme can be adopted right after this summer break, so that we can launch the call for proposals immediately afterwards. With the EDIDP we tested our capacity to discuss and to agree at European level between different institutions on defence matters, but the real test of course is now. We need concrete and ambitious projects and this is work that is ongoing right now. The EDIDP also paves the way to the fully-fledged European Defence Fund that we just proposed for the next budget, with EUR 13 billion in financing. This new programme is, of course, again building on the results of the agreement reached on the EDIDP. So I count on Parliament and I count on the Council to be able to agree on the future European Defence Fund in the same spirit of compromise in finding solutions and at the same pace as happened with the EDIDP. Thank you very much for your work.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: rapporteur for opinion for IMCO. Mr President, I was rapporteur for advice in IMCO, and I wanted to emphasise the importance for the internal market of a defence industry. All too often we see each Member State working on its own projects, when it could be so much more efficient to come up with new products together with other companies from other Member States. We see the successes in research programmes, such as Horizon 2020, the future Horizon Europe, where cooperation is central, and this must also be possible in defence. I'll make sure the budget doesn't get away from civil investigations. This should remain the rule in the new programmes after 2020. I am pleased to see that the door is being opened to cooperation with companies from countries outside the European Union, because we must also involve our foreign partners in these programmes when it comes to the strategic interest.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I thank Mrs Grossetête for this excellent report and all those who have worked on it. Of course, it is regrettable that, after two world wars, in Europe we have to increase spending on the defence industry, but we have no choice, because the security of each Member State and the European Union must be put first. And if we have no choice, then we must try to do everything to increase the efficiency of the spending we are doing for the defence industry. I particularly appreciate the emphasis in the report on cooperation between Member States, because the scale economy is as important a law in the defence industry as in any other industry, and unfortunately, as the Commissioner said, in this industry we have incredible fragmentation, we have a multitude of types of weapons used by the Member States and this will have to be made more efficient. I also very much appreciate that the report emphasises the incentives for small and medium-sized enterprises to participate in this programme.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D- Madam President, I join in the thanks to Mrs Grossetête, who has tried to find a compromise as broad as possible. The observation was mentioned: there is not enough cooperation in the Industrial Sector of European Defence. At the same time, unfortunately, many Member States are equipping themselves with non-European suppliers, as illustrated by the example of Belgian fighter jets that are American. The aim is therefore to promote joint initiatives, initially, at the research and development stage, in order to gain competitiveness and better match future equipment projects to European needs, in the hope that Member States will ultimately be encouraged to equip themselves 'made in Europe'. Even though I am not a strong militarist, as everyone knows, I share this approach. Indeed, to reject this programme is to maintain the status quo, and the status quo will not have the effect of constraining the military-industrial complex, but rather will simply give it the latitude it currently has, just as it will leave the field open to certain Member States to continue buying non-European. I would like to point out a few factual points mentioned by Mrs Grossetête: with regard to the eligibility criteria - three companies from at least three Member States, the specific inclusion of mid-sized companies to cover the whole of European geography, exemptions for non-European entities with sites on the territory of the Union, via compartmentalization - the point of equilibrium has been found. Moreover, it is taken up almost as it is in the proposal of the European Defence Fund. However, it would have been nice to have a time to evaluate this mechanism in order to be able to attest to its waterproofing. It should be noted that in the proposal for a European defence fund, the new Article 7 on ethics fills a gap, but it will require a strong reinforcement. In conclusion, we will have to vote on the joint declaration on the funding of this programme, I regret that Parliament's position, which asked for fresh money for this new priority, has not been heard. However, I warn the Council and the Commission in view of the future European fund. For the next programming period, the punctured programs will require considerable resources, so it will no longer be possible to proceed by making the budget cavalry. If Europe is to be present on all fronts, it will need a much more ambitious multi-year financial framework. I will therefore, of course, vote for Mrs Grossetête's report.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I also join in congratulating the rapporteur. You have defended the European Parliament's position very valiantly and persistently in these negotiations, and we have indeed succeeded in defending our position, many of its key aspects, during the trilogue, which makes this fund beneficial for all Member States by also creating new forms and prospects for cooperation in the defence sector.  It was important for the ECR Group that this new fund be used to increase the competitiveness of our businesses across the Union. At the same time, he sought to create new forms of cooperation, not just to replicate what has been done so far. The precondition for the cooperation of at least three different companies from three Member States will help to achieve this objective, and I consider this to be a major achievement – colleagues have already mentioned this. Secondly, it is important that in this way we will also help small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as mid-caps, to create the final product necessary for our economic growth. That is why we applaud all these bonuses for SMEs and mid-caps. This is also what this project is talking about.  Moreover, as the previous previous previous member pointed out, a balance has been struck between the need to open the programme to non-European third-country companies and the realistic requirements of this programme.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Françoise Grossetête for the excellence of her work and the cooperation we have had with her.  It is good news that we are voting on this European industrial development programme in the field of defence. Together, Parliament and Member States are sending a strong message about the importance of this programme by reaching a strong and rapid agreement. The need to pool our defence needs at EU level gives rise to the emergence of bilateral and multilateral initiatives, such as announcements of Franco-German industrial collaboration, permanent structural collaboration at 25 or most recently the European 9-a-side intervention initiative. But, while supporting these initiatives, we believe it is more effective to move, like this programme, towards a common framework at a community level.  Everything has been said about the content of this program and the agreement we had, both on its funding, its deployment model and also on the fact - I stress - that management is centralized. We must realize that there is no power without military-industrial complex. I know it is a dirty word, but it is a word that actually needs to be mentioned. When we look at our Chinese and Russian transatlantic neighbours, we see that all their industry and their space, aeronautics and digital technology exists, thrives and competes with us through the transfer of the military to the civilian. This complex is the basis of military power but, thanks to its civilian benefits, it is also the pillar of economic development. It is high time that Europe had it and this programme is one of the most interesting to create a real military-industrial complex. I know that the basis of our deliberation is industrial and we hope that this small industrial seed will give us a solid tree towards a European defence. 68 years ago, the vote of the French National Assembly condemned the European Defence Community. Things have changed a lot since then. The need is growing, and the danger is pressing. It is therefore time that, from this mechanism and the one that follows, we can develop a genuine Community defence policy for our fellow citizens in Europe. This first step is encouraging and we will support it.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Parliament's agreement with the Commission and the Council on the defence industry essentially validates the further militarisation of the Union, through increased investment in military research and military equipment. GUE/NGL categorically rejects this agreement, as it is unacceptable and disastrous for peoples to use funds from the Union budget and development programmes to finance the defence industry. The available allocation must be given to the real needs of people who, as a result of the economic crisis, are affected by unemployment and poverty. That is why we urgently call for an end to the financing of the war industry and wars, for money to be given for peace and solidarity, for the reindustrialisation of the South, for the creation of new quality jobs and for research to serve the real needs of society.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, few political adages have been more destructive than ‘if you wish to have peace, prepare for war’, which has been used as a moral justification by the belligerent since the Romans imposed their version of peace at the point of a sword. Tomorrow we will vote on a proposal to divert half a billion euros, that could be invested in useful and peaceful projects, towards the development of new weaponry, and particularly drones. Despite Parliament’s resolution that this should be fresh money, 60% of it will come from existing civilian programmes, so we will be investing in weaponry instead of improving communications and satellite technology.  This agenda is being driven by our continent’s powerful arms companies, which have more than doubled their lobbying budget in the last five years, and it seems to have worked. The EU Defence Fund is set to put nearly EUR 40 billion in these companies’ pockets over the next 10 years. That is over 30 times larger than the EU’s budget for human rights. Sadly, I fear some colleagues on the left of this House will have believed the lobbyists’ argument that funding arms protects jobs, but to defend these jobs that thrive on death and destruction, while ignoring the life-giving jobs that this same money could support in just and sustainable sectors, is a tragic failure of imagination. As Greens, we are committed to a European Union that was founded on peace and continues to support peaceful and secure livelihoods through its aid budget. But we should take note of the fact that the absurd inconsistency is there between spending public money to repair the damage caused by the very weapons that we are subsidising through budgets like the European Defence Industrial Development Programme. I strongly urge my colleagues to vote against this report. If you truly wish for peace, then prepare for peace by transferring the massive defence support budget to the EU’s peacekeeping and human rights activities.

name: Jonathan BULLOCK
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, so, the proposal is to establish a European Defence Industrial Development Programme to fund research into defence technologies, to acquire defence capabilities and promote joint purchase and maintenance of defence equipment, with a EUR 500 million budget for the programme. This is just part of the EU’s belief that ‘more Europe’ is needed, and yet another step along the way to the creation of an EU army and defence capability. We in UKIP pointed out, during our referendum, that there is a desire to set up this EU defence force. Indeed, the cat is now out of the bag: our colleague over there said: ‘It is so that Europe can defend itself in the future.’ Well, I suppose the EU is going that way, with one flag and one anthem, and it is now going to have one army as well. It is something we will oppose. Britain does very well with its UK defence spending and with our equipment, and, of course, all our projects tend to involve spending in the UK. Well, this proposal is all about funding things between three different Member States, so the UK would end up contributing but not gaining under the proposal. UKIP is against any further EU harmonisation dictated by the Commission in Brussels, and I believe that this proposal should be firmly rejected.

name: Christelle LETARD-LECHEVALIER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, the aim of promoting the development and excellence of the European defence industry is positive, as is the aim of encouraging Member States to buy equipment from EU countries rather than third countries. Unfortunately, your aim is not to organise the interoperability of the armies of sovereign European nations but to move towards a European defence, described by Mr Juncker as inevitable. The programme you are proposing, in seeking to reduce the number of weapons systems in Europe, aims to organise the interdependence of our armies and defence industries at the expense of their autonomy. Your plans run counter to national sovereignty and independence, which in the field of defence are non-negotiable. Moreover, this programme is presented as a two-year test of what the Future Defence Industrial Policy of the European Union could be. It is clear that it will not play this role since you intend to set up the European Defence Fund, without having yet been able to draw the consequences of this first programme. We also regret that the DIDP programme allows european funds to finance non-European defence industries based on our soil and not exclusively by European companies. Despite your ambitions, you can't even defend our interests. The submission of this programme to the YOke of NATO also proves this.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, the proposal to establish a European industrial development programme for the defence sector is not only an unnecessary action, it is at the same time an insult and a challenge for the peoples of all European states, who see the reduction in spending on social security and social benefits, education, health and tackling unemployment. Above all, however, it is a challenge against the Greek people, whom the European Union, in violation of all notions of logic, solidarity and law, has impoverished with the measures of the Memorandum and will maintain its austerity until 2060. It is now asking him to contribute EUR 500 million to the industrial development programme. On several occasions since this step, I have pointed out that of all the countries of the European Union only Greece and Cyprus receive a threat officially expressed by Turkey. No other country, including Russia and China, has threatened a European Union country with war. On the other hand, if that were the case, there is NATO, which is a defence organisation. So why should the European Union become a defence alliance? Against whom will he use this power he acquires? As a former military man and as a Greek... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Madam President, those of us who envision a truly strong and united Europe, all we have to do is defend a Europe with a strong defence capability and capability. There cannot be a strong Europe without a strong Europe that can defend, as my dear colleague Esteban very aptly, defends its own model of defence, but also ensures the sovereignty and borders of its member countries. That is why we support with all our might the strengthening of the European Union's defence capacity, so that the European Union is truly autonomous in the face of any threats. We support the development of industrial know-how, we support the development of the Competences and Capabilities of the European Union. I believe that the objective towards all this effort must be one: funding and investment in defence; that the European Union can safeguard the sovereignty and external borders of its Member States from any external risk.  We are not satisfied that Member States of the European Union, such as Greece and Cyprus, are subjected to daily threats from Turkey, they suffer daily violations of their sovereign rights, without a single reaction and possibility on the part of the European Union, despite the fact that it remains our only stable and powerful ally. We also believe that this European Union's defence capability and the protection of industrial know-how must be under rules and principles. The Member States of the European Union cannot equip, strengthen military countries that have an aggressive and expansionist policy, such as Turkey. It is therefore necessary to rule that European defence equipment and industrial know-how cannot be provided in these countries.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by welcoming the rapporteur and her team for the excellent work they have done, and we are therefore in a position to move forward with the negotiations so that the implementation of this programme is as rapid as possible. Today we have new geostrategic challenges that require the European Union to strengthen its own security capabilities, while strengthening the ability to participate equally in extended partnerships to maintain peace and prevent conflicts on a global scale. The development of a stronger European defence industry is also a necessary condition for ensuring the safety of European citizens and generating positive externalities by sharing innovation with traditional industries and the economy as a general.  Strategic autonomy to defend ourselves is the best way to ensure peace, and we know that the guarantee of peace is one of the greatest acquisitions of the European project in its 60 years of existence. The eligibility conditions also express a European matrix because it has excluded the financing of products and actions that may be related to weapons of mass destruction, personal mines or other weapons prohibited by international conventions. European control of the beneficiary consortia and the projects developed is also ensured, as well as the location within the European Union of the development and production process.  It is therefore essential that the European Defence Fund, proposed about a year ago, will be in place on 1 January 2019, ensuring sound prospects for European industry from 2020.      The European Fund of 500 million is a starting point that must take into account its effective use by European industry, the promotion of technological innovation for defence purposes in a broad sense, and the inclusion of small and medium-sized enterprises in the supported consortia.  Moreover, sustainable and widespread economic and social development in the territory is also part of a modern concept of defence. With the appropriate constraints to the specifics of the sector, the more small and medium-sized Enterprises and European knowledge centres are involved, the greater the rooting and success of the programme. Getting off to a good start, with a focus on financial reallocation that takes investment in other areas, is an important step for Europe's information, at a time when diplomacy and economic competitiveness cannot be disconnected from the deterrent force of the risks of war conflict.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Madam President, the European Defence Industrial Development Programme compromise is reasonable and worth supporting. I will make two remarks though. Firstly, Ms Bieńkowska stressed security and Ms Grossetête defence, and this area is still predominantly intergovernmental. Therefore, the role of Parliament’s Subcommittee on Security and Defence (SEDE) in drawing up this kind of report should be enhanced in future. Secondly, if we are talking about security and defence and threats to both, we need to mention the role of NATO and to avoid speaking so much about strategic autonomy. The role of the USA and the future of the UK are still extremely important in providing our security. There has been no withdrawal by the USA, even under the Trump administration. On the contrary, there has been an increase in funding for European security.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: Mr President, let us take a look at the EU's cooperation projects. That is the Greek crisis: zero cooperation. Eurocrisis: zero cooperation. Accession Turkey: one big fiasco, very very expensive. And finally, the migration crisis. Well, we've all seen that over the past few days: divided to the bone. What are we going to do? Build a European army. No, that's going to work. The Commission is a group of DO-it-yourselfers who fail to assemble a soapbox and then decide to build a Formula 1 car. Look, that's never going to work, of course, and that's very dangerous. Only one diagnosis applies to this phenomenon, and it is from addiction care: the EU is a fiasco addict. The EU is a crisis junkie.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: I think that respect in this House is quite something important that should be remembered again and again.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her There is also another point of view: it is not acceptable for the financially strong arms industry to be helped further and further by EU funds. For the EDIDP, there will be reallocations for existing programmes. 116 million will be taken out of the Connecting Europe Facility alone. I wonder whether high-tech weapons should actually be promoted instead of sustainable infrastructure projects. Do you really believe that one questionable programme after another would make Europe a global player? Where is the common foreign policy? That would strengthen Europe! The European Defence Industrial Development Programme continues to fail to solve the problems of existing duplication of arms procurement. It should also aim to reduce the overall procurement costs in the arms sector through efficient pooling and sharing between EU Member States. From this point of view, it is difficult to explain why the programme adds to the expenditure on Defence for the European Member States. Moreover, I do not believe that there should be any EU funding for arms exports.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I wanted to express my full support for the Defence Industry Development Programme in Europe and I congratulate the European Commission , Commissioner Bieńkowska, personally, for taking this initiative. I would also like to thank Françoise Grossetête for preparing a great report.  I see three main benefits of this program. Firstly, in terms of safety. The European Union is an economic power, but from a defensive, military and political point of view it has remained a dwarf. I see that this programme may be the first step towards creating a genuine common defence policy. This is very important in the current unpredictable world. Secondly, the economic benefits, as has already been mentioned. The defence industry is a source of innovation and will certainly be an impetus for the development of other areas of production. Thirdly, it is an area that has not yet been covered by European integration. This will support further links between countries. I am convinced that if all countries are included in this programme – and I call for it – this will certainly be an important direction for the development of European integration.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The German Socialists and Democrats support progress in the EU's Common Security and Defence Policy and want to make European defence capacities more efficient and effective as part of a pooling and sharing approach. However, we are opposed to European subsidies for the defence industry in the Member States without actually achieving these efficiencies. Armaments are not normal commodities and should also be seen as an external and security policy instrument. Accordingly, the establishment of the programme is already absolutely problematic, precisely through the Committee on Industry. If European funds are spent on armaments, then the products produced from them must also be controlled by the European Parliament. We demand that, in accordance with the position paper on the EU's common security and defence policy from the S&D Group, which we adopted last year, no money from existing budget lines should be invested in the arms industry. But that is precisely what is to be decided on the basis of this text. The results of the trialogue between the Commission, the Member States and Parliament do not in any way reflect the position of the European Parliament. I therefore recommend voting against this text.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the European industrial development programme in the field of defence reinforces the militarisation of the European Union, gives funds to the European military industrial complex and all this at a time when reductions in wages and pensions have been imposed, the dissolution of the social state throughout Europe and in particular in Greece, and even calls on the Greek people, who have been constantly impoverished and impoverished by the troika. , to contribute in this direction. The troika which also broke up the Greek defence industry and from then on there is a serious problem: who are those who support and equip Turkey? We have seen the European defence industry arm Turkey, a country that is aggressive towards Greece and Cyprus, a country that threatens another European force. Is it possible to allow this? So are we going to give support to the European industry that sells arms to Turkey? Is it time to ban the sale of military equipment to Turkey?

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would like to express my full solidarity with the just struggle of the interpreters.  This European programme of industrial development in the field of defence is very demonstration of the nature of the dangers that the European Union carries for the future of the peoples of the continent, particularly in view of the deepening of its militaristic dimension.  This is a leap that can't help but worry all peace lovers. It is a question of ensuring budgetary resources, diverted from programmes for civil and peaceful purposes, to finance research and development of armaments and, at subsequent stages, also the production and purchase of such armaments. It is millions of euros that will be poured into the military-industrial complex of the major European powers. Those who have never secured sufficient resources to achieve the much-proposed economic and social cohesion to combat the effects of the crisis, poverty, social injustices, to support development, do not hesitate now to channel resources to boost the war industry.  Deep down, they are consistent in their action. Those who threaten social progress and impose social retrogression on us are the ones that threaten peace. Here we express our firm opposition to this path.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Madam President, Commissioner Bieńkowska, Mrs Grossetête's excellent report contributes to a new perspective in the field of defence after 2020 and opens up a development window of opportunity. It is therefore necessary in principle to support it financially with a brave budget and at this level the proposals for the new 2027 budget have positive signs. It is necessary to support technologically, to encourage innovation, but also to consolidate standards in the Member States. It is necessary to emphasise the integration into the production chain of the European defence industry of small and medium-sized enterprises in the Member States.  In Greece we have the Greek defense systems, the Hellenic Aviation Industry, the Hellenic Vehicle Industry and, without neglecting the necessary repair, they can contribute with the know-how. With the integration of small and medium-sized enterprises in European industry, we are maintaining and creating jobs in an area where Europe must now be globally competitive.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I will start by saying that I want to and I am trying to look at this report very objectively. No one believes that they want war, but the European Union must strengthen its autonomy in the field of defence in order to guarantee the Union freedom of action around the globe. We have to be very realistic. The defence industry in the European Union must be globally competitive and this, in fact, is being stryd by this regulation.  The defence industry must be based on cooperation, innovation, research and I am certainly pleased that, in this regulation, with proposals from colleagues, in addition to the Commission proposal, we have integrated SMEs here, we have integrated cross-border collaboration. After all, some jobs are being created, and I am interested in producing in Europe, reindustrialising the European Union – sure, and civil – but also having this defence industry, instead of depending on imports, as we depend on many other areas.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We have come a long way, almost a revolution in such a short time. I recall the beginning of this Parliament's term of office and the disregard for both security and defence. Today it is precisely this subject that has been taken up in the grossetête report, and I must say that I am pleased about that. I am, of course, more concerned about the source of our sudden activity, so much interest and full consent. These were, I recall, primarily terrorist attacks. But it is very good that, finally, the issue of security and defence is in the mainstream interests of the European Parliament. I would like to draw attention to only one disturbing element that is of particular interest to me. Two programmes, Galileo m.in Copernicus, contributed to this programme. Today, both programmes need financial reinforcement. This means that the contribution created for this new – I repeat sensible – programme has unfortunately been occupied by problems in the Galileo and Copernicus programmes. I therefore call for them to be strengthened.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I want to thank all of the honourable Members for their remarks and for their comments. I am quite sure that with tomorrow’s vote this House will send a very clear and strong signal and a clear message for EU defence and for the security of EU citizens. Let me just underline two points. The first was one of the most deliberated points during the negotiations. There is a very restrictive participation of third countries in the programme. This was discussed at great length and I think again that on this point too, we have a very balanced and good agreement taking into account the specificity of the defence sector. The second point: there is no contradiction between what we are doing for European Union defence, and NATO. We are working in very good cooperation, and let me repeat and echo what I have said many times before: a stronger EU in defence is ultimately a stronger NATO. Thank you very much for your hard work and with the adoption of the programme, we are really at the turning point to delivering a credible defence union. Your work was wonderful; you are very devoted and engaged with the programme. Thank you very much for this.  Declarations from the Commission (in writing) Declaration from the Commission with support of the European Parliament concerning the implementation of the Programme In order to implement the European Defence Industrial Development Programme efficiently and ensure full consistency with other Union initiatives, the Commission intends to implement the programme under direct management in accordance with Article 62(1)(a) of the Financial Regulation. Declaration from the Commission concerning the preparation and adoption of the EDIDP work Programme In accordance with article 188 of Regulation N°1268/2012, the Commission is responsible for the preparation of the work programme.  In this context, the Commission notes that the list of priorities identified in the Regulation establishing the European Defence Industrial Development Programme should not be exhaustive and therefore, does not believe that the present case should constitute a precedent as to the margins of implementing powers granted to the Commission. Declaration from the Commission on the selection of experts for the evaluation of proposals under the Programme in the context of the award procedure The Commission will ensure that the experts selected in the database of independent experts referred to in Article XX have the necessary skills, experience and knowledge to duly perform their tasks. The Commission may use any relevant source including any information Member States may possess in this regard to this effect while respecting fully to the Financial Regulation. The Commission will ensure that Member States’ feedback with regard to the credentials of the experts in the database of independent experts will be taken into account to the greatest possible extent.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank my colleagues who have spoken. I would like to say that with this programme, of course, there is no question of funding the war. What we want is to ensure the protection of our fellow citizens in a world that is particularly unstable and where there are many threats. How can we explain to our fellow citizens that we do not want to do anything to try to coordinate the efforts of Member States in the area of the arms industry? Yes, we need strategic autonomy from the European Union, and I take as proof the words of the President of the United States, Donald Trump, who called on the European Union to ensure its own security and its own defence. So yes, this programme is deed to guarantee peace, not to wage war, but to guarantee the peace and security of our fellow citizens. So let's not caricature this program, it's an industrial program for innovation and competitiveness. It is not a European army, it is about equipping the European Union with the most advanced technologies, in particular to ensure cyber security. Are you going to tell our fellow citizens that you don't want to keep them safe? I'm signing up for it. This programme is an important step forward in the european defence framework.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Tuesday 3 July 2018.Written Statements (Rule 162)

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – We are living in turbulent times in which both the security and the stability of the EU and its Member States are under constant threat from various state and non—state actors. To guarantee the safety of its own citizens, the EU and its Member States must increase their cooperation in order to make the EU more protected and more independent in the area of defence. The best way to achieve greater cooperation in the field of defence, unarguably is the new European Defence Industrial Development Programme (EDIDP). The EDIDP, with a EUR 500 million budget for 2019—2020, is the best choice to make budget spending more efficient and stimulate innovation in defence. This is so because the European Defence Industrial Development Programme aims to fund the development phase (between research and production) of new and upgraded defence products and technologies in the EU, from studies through design, testing and up to the certification and development phases. This collaborative research projects in a long term perspective will stimulate the development of the EU defence market and competition between SMEs in the field. Last but not least, the launching of EDIDP is another step on the way to building a European Defence Union, which I fully support.

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing.- I welcome the European Defense Industry Development Program - it is also time to finally start doing something about European defense.Citizens across countries are calling for a more effective defense of the EU and are very sensitive to Russia's assertive policies, but also to the declining predictability of US behavior.I am convinced that tomorrow we will approve a program that will actively move us towards European strategic autonomy, but which will also encourage the European defense industry.I welcome the fact that the program will actively support small and medium-sized enterprises, but also medium-sized companies, the so-called Mid-caps.EDIDP is a model for the future European Defense Fund.At this point, I would like to express the hope that the European Defense Fund will also be designed to support European companies in particular and thus contribute to strengthening European strategic autonomy.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: in writing. - I am one of those people who believe that Europe must take more responsibility for its own security. Of course, the participation of 25 out of 28 EU countries in NATO is important, but own military and industrial capabilities will be increasingly important. Because scientific, research and industrial abilities ultimately determine the quality of the military's technical potential. It is disturbing, therefore, that research institutions and industry working for defense purposes in Europe struggle with many problems, which mainly include the low efficiency of distributed research and implementation and the scarcity of defense funds. It is worth recalling that Europe as a whole spends only 1.34% of GDP on defense. Therefore, it is a good idea to establish the European Defense Fund and to separate for the first time in the draft EU budget special funds for the improvement of security and defense, which in the next budget perspective should amount to EUR 32 billion. If these plans are implemented, then after 2021 we should see progress in the level of military technology in Europe.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Maria Gabriela Zoană, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on integrated statistics on agricultural holdings and repealing (EC) regulationsNo. 1166/2008 and (EU) No. 1337/2011 (COM (2016) 0786 - C8-0514 / 2016 - 2016/0389 (COD)) (A8-0300 / 2017).

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: Rapporteur. - Commissioner, Madam President, I would like to thank all the teams that have worked on this file, starting with Eurostat, the two Presidencies - the Estonian and the Bulgarian, the shadow rapporteurs who accompanied me throughout the case and, last but not least. line, to my predecessor, the current Prime Minister of Romania, Mrs. Viorica Dăncilă, who started this case. The Commission's initial proposal for a new regulation on integrated statistics on European farms was based on the idea of ​​simplifying data collection, reducing costs and administrative burdens, but also maintaining a flexible framework that can last and last. could adapt over time. We fully share these objectives, which have been the subject of our work and negotiations to find the balance between cost and flexibility. The process of collecting statistical data, in particular those on the structure of agricultural holdings, visibly influences decisions in future agricultural reforms, which ultimately affect farmers. The first pillar of this regulation is the 2020 agricultural census, and efforts have focused on reducing administrative burdens and pressure on farmers and, where possible, supplementing data from other existing databases. However, our biggest concern was to have a more accurate picture of the European agricultural area, from small farms to the largest structures. The second pillar is represented by statistical modules at regular intervals on various topics, such as agricultural labor, agricultural equipment, irrigation. Here we took care to keep a flexible framework, which would allow European statistics to evolve over time, but also so that a reasonable number of variables could be taken into account. The third pillar is the option of conducting ad hoc agricultural research. This was probably the most difficult point in the negotiations. First, there was a need to find an interinstitutional balance between delegated and implementing acts. Second, it was necessary to set a limit on the maximum number of variables. I know that some of you would like to have statistical information on various topics. Some could not be technically included in this file because they related to production statistics. Others were separate cases, national or local, which are already covered by national statistics. We regret that some animals, and in particular horses, could not be included in this census. An amendment has been tabled in the European Parliament to include horses in census data. Unfortunately, he did not obtain the necessary majority in the specialized commission. In addition, some countries no longer consider horses to be agricultural animals and we risk having a wrong picture of the number of horses in different countries. For other animals, such as quails or buffaloes, the herds are too small and too localized, and the statistical analysis would not have been conclusive. I remind you that, for horses and buffaloes, their number can be deduced from the national zootechnical registers. I believe, first of all, that we have reached a good agreement, which respects Parliament's mandate, guarantees the necessary flexibility for Eurostat but, at the same time, does not expose national statistical institutes to unforeseen administrative and financial costs. The Council agreed to withdraw the amendments concerning derogations from the Regulation on the protection of personal data (GDPR Regulation) aimed at creating specific statistical derogations from this Regulation. Thank you to the Council for the understanding I received. It would probably have been impossible for Parliament to reach an agreement if these amendments had not been withdrawn by the Council.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I wish to thank the rapporteur, Ms Zoană, and the shadow rapporteurs for their very constructive approach to the proposal, and their support during the process. Following fruitful cooperation between the three EU institutions, I believe we have reached our common objective. The Commission welcomes the agreement reached on this important regulation on integrated farm statistics. We are discussing today the re-ordering of the collection of data for structural farm statistics, since the common agricultural policy is one of our oldest policies and the first European service on the structure of agricultural holdings dates back to 1966. This is one of our oldest data-collection arrangements. With each new iteration we improve its relevance for the changing economy and for our policy priorities. This proposal will ensure the availability of the data that only farmers can provide for planning and monitoring the common agricultural policy, as well as for climate change, environmental and other important European Union policies. Information from the farmer that we do not need – such as geolocation or whether the farm is, for instance, in a mountainous area – will not be asked for. Comparable and flexible, modernised European agricultural statistics of high quality are also important for a fair single market and sustainable growth and, in general, for a better understanding of our rapidly changing world. I want to thank you for having recognised the need for this flexibility and made sure it remained in the final compromise text. This will ensure that data collection keeps pace with the evolution of the CAP, taking into account, too, the recent Commission proposals. Because, as you all know, data collection is an investment that pays for itself many times over. Knowledge is the base for good policymaking. That is why I particularly welcome the addition of information on young farmers. This will help us understand the intergenerational dynamics, and the interests and the needs of the new generation that we need so much in this sector. Not having these data, or having them only in an inflexible form, would in the end be much more expensive. That is why I believe that this final agreement on integrated farms statistics is a success for each institution, and that, first and foremost, it will be of great benefit to Europe’s farmers and rural communities today and tomorrow, and to our Member States.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, it is true that a priori we could think that statistics on agricultural holdings constitute a mere technical dossier, but the truth is that their importance is vital to be able to make effective use of the financial resources that we have. . Good data collection is essential to be able to analyze the real impact of the Common Agricultural Policy and to more precisely address the problems of our farmers and ranchers. The agreement adopted within the framework of this dossier respects Parliament's mandate and strikes a good balance between the administrative burdens borne by national managers and Eurostat, for which greater flexibility is provided. I therefore underline the importance of adopting this Decision as soon as possible. The deal should have been concluded no more and no less than under the Latvian Presidency, but we have had to wait until the Bulgarian Presidency to finalize it. However, this delay will not prevent three countries that want to bring forward the agricultural census planned for 2020 - Portugal, Greece and Spain - from doing so in order to coincide with their population censuses, which will allow them to reduce their expenses.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I congratulate you on the agreement reached in the trialogue on modernizing and improving the European framework for collecting integrated farm statistics. Issues such as the gender and workforce structure, young farmers and the depopulation of the countryside, the concentration of land and the greater pressure exerted by urbanization and certainly by greening, the use of soils, the change of destination of the same and the forestry are just a few examples of areas where the production of reliable statistics is essential for making informed policy decisions. With these new rules, we will finally have better statistics for the implementation and monitoring of the common agricultural policy without the additional burden of data collection. These rules address in particular the shortcomings identified in the assessment of the European system of agricultural statistics, streamlining and updating the collection of statistics at farm level, within a single framework, and allowing greater flexibility for the rapid introduction of new surveys. data.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, data collection has played an important role in the development of the common agricultural policy since its inception and is an essential tool in keeping to evidence-based policymaking. It allows policymakers not just to assess how current policies are being implemented but also to monitor trends and better prepare us for future reforms. As we embark on another CAP reform, it is only right that we continue to ensure that we are using the best available methods of data protection. However, we must also be mindful of the importance of the simplification of the CAP – and these aims do not necessarily contradict each other. Crucially, new technology, such as satellite data and important IT systems, have the potential to ensure, on the one hand, that the data collected is useful and accurate, while at the same time reducing the administrative burden on producers. In my opinion, there also needs to be greater cooperation and joined-up thinking between the agriculture departments of the Member States and regions, and then farmers can ensure as smooth a process as possible.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. - Mr. Chairman, Mr. Vice-President, I would certainly like to express my support for this long-awaited report at the outset, but we have it and I believe that integrated farm statistics will now be much more efficient, as my colleague Zoana says, and more flexible and rational. What I would definitely like to emphasize, one of the key topics of these statistics is the issue of climate change. Everything that affects agriculture, we know today, is certainly, among other things, climate change. It is in this context that I think it is very important that we have more precise, exact data on what farmers are facing today. However, I want to highlight one of my personal experiences: I asked for data, statistics, classic agricultural statistics for what is produced organically and what is produced under a protected geographical origin as an agricultural product. Of course I received information on how many hectares we have under organic agriculture in the European Union and of course I received information on how many hectares we have under protected products, ie protected geographical origin, but I did not receive information on how many of these protected products are produced organically. And vice versa, of course. So we lack statistics. It is very important, because I believe that the competitiveness of the European economy is precisely in that part of the agricultural holdings.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the collection of statistics is important if we are to plan for a better common agricultural policy, and therefore this proposal is to be welcomed. I am especially pleased that our own priorities have been included in the final outcome, and will form part of the new service, specifically in relation to farm ownership models, information on farm transfers and the age profile of our farming community. Of course, statistics are only as useful as the purpose they are put to. We have known for years, for example, that we have a serious problem in attracting young people into farming. We have known for years that there is a massive disparity in the CAP payment levels that go to the richest farm interests in comparison to most farmers, and we have also known for years that peripheral farmers face greater obstacles than most. Yet this information has not been sufficiently acted upon and the problems have got worse. So, as we will now have an improved information-gathering system in place, it must be matched with improved reactions to the issues which those statistics expose.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, I am not a retrograde of agriculture, I am not opposed to the modernization of techniques, I am not against the use of technologies to develop our profession and I am not against either to the collection of data to improve the effectiveness of a policy, in this case the common agricultural policy (CAP), but what appears in this text frankly strikes me as extremely worrying. Already because the Union, champion of failure in agricultural policy, makes us believe that it is for lack of statistics that the CAP does not work. What a nerve! So, under the pretext of improving a flawed policy, the Commission is here, casually, establishing a gigantic collection of personal and professional data. Everything goes there. Sex, gender, age, commercial structure of farms, good ecological practices and good cultivation methods, etc. What you call rationalization, I call surveillance policy. Therefore, it is of course out of the question for me to vote for a text intended in reality to spy on farmers.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: - (NL) Mr President, to measure is to know. This certainly applies to agriculture. If we want to steer the common agricultural policy, we need accurate data. How else can we know exactly what the situation is with our rural areas and what the impact is of, among other things, climate change, but also of the changed social climate in the countryside? By collecting data meticulously for years, we can better indicate trends but also predict trends. One of the clear trends is of course the rapid decline in the number of farmers, which really worries me. In the new CAP, we must take measures to find a supportive solution for this. Colleagues, although the collection of data in the agricultural sector has been happening since 1966, I need not tell you that in 2018 this data is even more needed than ever. Modernizing the data collection provided for in this legislation is therefore desperately needed as far as I am concerned. In closing, I would like to emphasize one more thing. When measuring various rural indicators, it has recently been noticed that the internet connections of rural municipalities are not always optimal. Nevertheless, the presence of a high-quality and smooth internet is absolutely necessary, not only to allow people a social digital life, but also to be able to engage in precision agriculture, for example. I really hope to see improvements here in the near future.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: - Mr President, first of all I would like to express my thanks and congratulations to Maria Gabriella Zoanǎ for the quality of her work, which was not simple, since she took over from Mrs Dǎncilǎ, on this essential report for the future of agriculture. We know today that statistics are an integral part of our work on the pursuit of common agricultural policies, but I would like to draw the attention of all of us here and say that statistics do not exempt us from adopting a vision. prospective to define the common agricultural policy. I think that we cannot rely exclusively on statistics to build the projection, we must also put into perspective political visions that integrate the elements of common agricultural activity. I would also like to say that we must measure the complexity of statistics, not overload the weight of the administration in data collection and rely on modern tools. And finally, I would like to express my regret for the equine industry which has not been recognized in these statistics and I can only regret it.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the heterogeneity that characterizes the Union and the profound reviews of the common agricultural policy over the last ten years have highlighted the need to standardize our system of agricultural statistics at European level, making it more flexible and overcoming the shortcomings and rigidity of the current legislation. For this reason, with a view to modernization and simplification, the regulation we are about to vote on will ensure a significant reduction in bureaucratic burdens, both for administrations and, in particular, for our farmers, but maintaining, as fortunately wished by our rapporteur , a common level, high standards and protection of personal data. We must, dear Commissioner, continue on this path, especially in view of the discussions on the reform of the common agricultural policy that await us and we cannot allow European farmers to be forced to live with different agricultural policies between countries, or even between regions, risking completely lose that common vision towards our agricultural sector.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - President! I, too, would like to pay tribute to Mrs Zoană for this very excellent work, and let me make a few comments on this otherwise really great result. In order for EU statistics on the structure of agricultural holdings to be comparable and coherent, it is necessary to build infrastructure for smart solutions and to encourage the acquisition of digital skills. However, this process cannot be treated completely separately from rural communities - digital developments are already mainly targeted at urban areas. Therefore, in addition to coordinating all funds affecting the countryside, for example along the concept of 'smart villages', there is a great need to extend statistical attention and methodology to small settlements. I am pleased that the 'smart villages' pilot project I have launched is nearing completion, that our second, our so-called preparatory action, will be launched soon, and that the so-called 'smart villages' result indicator will already appear in the proposal for the future of the common agricultural policy. Thank you very much!

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
