text: - Congratulations to the rapporteur on the report, which I very much support.We need statistics in agriculture very much, European agriculture is very different and if we want to respond to challenges such as how to respond to a large concentration of land, how to respond to the problem of a declining number of young entrepreneurs, we must first have good data.From this data, which we already have to some extent, we can see how different European agriculture is.And how will we use the basis in the new agricultural policy to be able to adapt these strategic agricultural programs in individual countries to the ownership structure, the age structure of the owners.On the other hand, agriculture is increasingly demanding transparency in the use of money, traceability of products, and therefore it is very important that we have quality data, well processed, and as my colleague Szanyi said, also digitalization in rural areas in the smart villages project..

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman!At the previous session of the European Parliament, my report on barriers to access to culture was adopted.I would like to emphasize that it would not have been possible not so much to adopt this report as to write it at all, if not for the Eurostat and Eurobarometer surveys.It was thanks to the statistical data that it was finally possible to build a common denominator for a certain knowledge - not only about certain attitudes, about certain behaviors, about a specific participation in culture, but also about us - about Europeans.I would like to emphasize clearly that knowledge is a very important tool, but I have only one question on this occasion - does the introduction of the GDPR, all these elements, principles, data protection, make it difficult to collect data, those that are considered particularly important in this report?

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, from the very beginning I have been saying that I support this report and I am starting from the idea that statistics are necessary in order to be able to make the right decision. We are talking about the CAP, we are talking about the common agricultural policy and it is obvious that we need to have statistics in order to make a good decision. I congratulate the rapporteurs who have worked and I believe that the improved form, since the Commission proposal, with the proposals of my colleagues in the European Parliament, shows that we have taken a step forward. We will know the situation of farms, the situation of new farms that appear, but, of course, I also emphasize the idea that the methodology, data collection, statistics we need not to add very high costs, especially for new farmers, young farmers and for start-up farmers. However, it is important not to treat the issue, as a colleague said, as espionage. If we start from the idea that we have an internal market, if we have a common agricultural policy, we cannot talk about espionage, but we can talk about knowledge.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, it is important, of course, to have statistics on the agricultural sector, to know what is happening with the properties, to know if land reclamation is taking place, to know how many farmers are actually engaged. I also believe that very specific information is needed on products of designation of origin, on products that have a geographical origin, and even more so as we have for fifteen years the operation of international conventions that have effectively liberalized imports of agricultural products from third countries and we want to know What is the current state of protection of designations of origin and whether farmers can really continue to be involved with these products or that farms are currently being dismantled? What is the situation? I think statistics can give specific answers.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, almost half of the European Union is used for agricultural activities and that is why it is particularly important to have a collection of statistics and, above all, research on agricultural holdings. This data will enable us to identify, on the one hand, the needs and problems faced by farmers and, on the other hand, the opportunity to make the appropriate reforms to the common agricultural policy in order to address these problems. But in order to be truly successful, two factors must be taken into account. The first is the frequency with which these recordings are made. The period of the decade between two recordings does not guarantee that we will have much success in this endeavor. A second element that must be taken into account is the specificities faced by each region of the European Union. The needs of the European South are different, and especially Greece, and the needs of the North are different.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the Members of this Parliament for their reactions. This proposal will allow us to satisfy new and emerging data needs better, more flexibly and faster. It will bring more comparability and more coherence in statistics on the structure of EU agriculture, and it will ensure that the costs and the burden of data collection for producers and providers will be reduced. That is why the Commission is pleased with the compromise you reached.  Congratulations again to Madam rapporteur and all those who worked very hard on this, and for tomorrow I hope that Parliament will be able to support it in the vote.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, I would like to thank all my colleagues who have spoken. As you can see, even an eminently technical file can give an opportunity for interesting debates. As I said in the introduction, I believe that statistics are an essential source of information and fuel public debates on a daily basis, so they must be as accurate as possible. We all want to have information on various aspects of the agricultural sector, but the costs, in some cases, can be exaggerated for information that, with modern techniques, can be quite accurately approximated. I would like to return to the fact that this regulation concerns the factors of production in European agriculture and not the production itself. There is a separate European regulation, which organizes production statistics and, as far as I understand from the discussions we had at the European Commission, this regulation is also to be revised. I am convinced that the agreement we have reached is a good one and will allow agricultural statistics to evolve for at least the next ten years, if not longer, so the balance between predictability and flexibility is essential. So tomorrow, I invite you to support this agreement with your vote. Once again, I would like to thank all those who worked on this file and those who spoke today.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 3 July 2018.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the report by Francisco Assis, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on violation of the rights of indigenous peoples in the world, including land grabbing (2017/2206(INI)) (A8—0194/2018).

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: reporter. - Mr President, this is the first report by the European Parliament to address a reality that concerns about 370 million people, an estimated number of the world's population of indigenous peoples. Especially unprotected and vulnerable in the context of globalization and climate change, indigenous peoples continue to be victims of homicide, aggression, forced evictions from their ancestral lands, arbitrary detentions, persecution and intimidation, racism and exclusion. As if that were not enough, they have alarming levels of poverty, disease and illiteracy, insufficient political participation and representation and an accelerated loss of their cultural and linguistic heritage. But the scope of this report goes beyond the issue of the rights of indigenous peoples by covering the phenomenon of “land grabbing”, which affects not only these peoples, but also countless peasant communities spread across various regions of the world. It is known that the growing demand for natural resources on the part of the extractive industry and the agro-industrial sector places enormous pressure on territories traditionally inhabited and cultivated by such communities, with conflicts over land use sometimes leading to serious violations of their human rights. One of the darkest aspects of this panorama is the number of murders of defenders of the rights of indigenous peoples and of the right to land that has occurred in recent years. In 2017 alone, 312 activists were murdered, two-thirds of whom were defending this type of rights. The European Union must therefore give more emphasis to the situation of these communities in its foreign policy, in particular in its dialogue with third countries on human rights and in trade, cooperation and development agreements. This report proposes, moreover, a set of initiatives to improve the situation of these communities and to protect their rights, starting with the adoption and implementation of the relevant international treaties by all the Member States of the European Union. In this chapter, it is never necessary to underline ILO Convention 169, as it is the only legally binding treaty. But a more robust approach is also proposed in the field of European Union extraterritorial obligations and domestic activities with an extraterritorial impact. This entails, from the outset, ensuring that violations of the rights of these peoples that, directly or indirectly, result from the extraterritorial action of companies and investors within the jurisdiction of the European Union are properly investigated and sanctioned. It is in this sense that it is proposed, in this report, to create a European mechanism that allows these communities to make complaints about these violations, regardless of the country where they register, in order to have effective access to justice. On the other hand, it is recommended that development projects supported by the European Union with an impact on the lives of these peoples scrupulously respect their right to be informed and consulted in advance, in order to obtain their prior consent. In parallel, the European Union must carry out impact studies before concluding trade and cooperation agreements. Finally, we cannot underestimate the importance of these communities for the conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity and to stop the phenomenon of deforestation. That is also why the European Union must include them in its strategies for sustainable development and the fight against climate change. This is, moreover, a dimension that is sought to be emphasized in this report. Indigenous peoples are often, as we all know, completely invisible. People without a voice, seen as anachronisms, as people who are too many, who no longer have a place in our world. The European Union must make an effort to give them more visibility, and we hope that, with this report, it has made a small contribution to this. Before I finish, I would like to highlight the way in which the dialogue with all parliamentary groups has taken place on this issue. This report was greatly enriched by several contributions that were made by representatives of various parliamentary groups in this parliamentary assembly. I am convinced that, therefore, the conditions are created for a stronger report to emerge and a report mainly supported by broad support from Members of this European Parliament.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I thank you all and especially the rapporteur, Mr Assis, for his report. We share your concerns. The human rights situation of indigenous people is extremely precarious in many countries and we see a rapid rise in the incidence of land grabbing, with increasing violence against indigenous rights and environmental defenders. Therefore, in 2017, we stepped up our support for indigenous peoples, and for human rights defenders working on land, environment, biodiversity and climate, through the European Union human rights defenders mechanism. We also share the concern over the multiple discrimination suffered by persons with disabilities and by women. The joint staff working document on indigenous peoples by the European External Action Service and the Commission, of October 2016, reflects the action we are taking to address these concerns. The May 2017 Council conclusions on indigenous peoples touch on and match the policy positions expressed in the Assis report. These conclusions also confirm the European Union’s support for the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples, as well as the outcome of the 2014 World Conference on Indigenous Peoples. In relation to land grabbing, let me assure you that the European Union attaches vital importance to land governance and secure access to, and tenure of, land. The EU is supporting land governance in about 40 countries, with a total budget of EUR 240 million. In this regard, let me give the example of our programme in Colombia that was also important to the peace process there. Thanks to European Union support, 280 000 hectares were awarded through collective title, benefiting some 8 000 indigenous and Afro-Colombian families living in the neighbourhood of protected areas of national parks. We also recently concluded an agreement with Honduras which promotes the rights of indigenous and Afro-Honduran peoples on issues such as land tenure and titling, and we are hoping to conclude soon an agreement with Guyana that seeks to raise guarantees for improved protection of Amerindian peoples and the land rights of forest-dependent local communities. The Assis report calls for the updating of the EU land policy guidelines from 2004, which the Commission is already considering. Implementing the principles of sustainable and responsible governance of land is key to stopping land grabbing, but we believe, too, that full implementation of the UN guiding principles on business and human rights is relevant in this context. We will also further reflect on the call for the Commission to launch an EU action plan on responsible business conduct. Mr President, honourable Members, allow me now briefly to touch on other recommendations in the report. The report addresses the issue of the training of delegation staff on the rights of indigenous peoples. In fact, the rights of indigenous peoples is a subject that features regularly in the human rights training programmes we provide annually to our staff but we also know more is needed, so we will certainly make efforts to enhance such training opportunities. The report also attaches importance to ensuring dialogues and consultations with indigenous peoples, at both national and regional level, as the May 2017 Council conclusions note too. Against that background, we are constantly working to enhance and explore ways of consulting and engaging with indigenous peoples more effectively. Such engagement could include discussions on the idea expressed in the report of establishing a complaints mechanism for indigenous peoples who have been affected adversely by EU action and cooperation. We firmly believe that the main challenge ahead of us lies in the implementation of the wealth of existing international and EU-level policy and legal frameworks, and it is in this light that we concur with the report on the urgency of ensuring consistency in all EU policies and actions pertaining to or affecting indigenous peoples. We would also very much welcome the European Parliament’s appointment of a standing rapporteur on indigenous peoples’ rights. Should this be realised, we will stand ready to cooperate with and support the mandate holder. Mr President, honourable Members, thank you once again for a very rich report and for your attention. I look forward to our discussion.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. - Mr President, recently, here in the European Parliament, we have nominated a finalist for the Sakharov Prize named Lolita Chávez. For the first time a woman, a defender of human and environmental rights and, above all, indigenous. It was a step in the right direction, and this report is also a step forward. It is time to recognize the multiple violations of rights that the indigenous poor are suffering: land grabbing —of course—, serious impacts of climate change and also the abuses of large corporations —including European ones. And, in particular, women are often the ones on the front lines: they are often harassed, extorted, and one in three - I repeat: one in three - has been raped at some time in her life. And this violence - often unpunished, unfortunately - occurs all too often at the hands of public officials or, also, where extractive industries or agribusiness operate on indigenous lands. From the European Union we cannot allow it. No, we cannot allow it. Our companies, our products, our investments cannot have the slightest relationship with the violations of human and environmental rights of indigenous peoples. Neither Lolita Chávez nor anyone else was born to be harassed, extorted or killed.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: , on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mister President! In 2007, after more than 20 years of negotiations, the United Nations adopted a declaration on the rights of indigenous peoples. For the first time, the indigenous peoples' right to self-determination and control over their land and the mineral resources stored there was recognized. Significantly, the governments of four states that until recently had not even been willing to grant citizenship to the original residents of their states voted against: the United States, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand. Like all declarations of the United Nations, this UN declaration on the rights of indigenous peoples will only become effective if it is incorporated into legally binding international treaties or national legislation. But that's missing. So the rights of indigenous peoples continue to be disregarded in most cases when it comes to the exploitation of resources that are in their settlement area. Their rights to self-determination and the preservation of their culture are not respected. Even the only norm to date for the legal protection of indigenous peoples, ILO Convention 169, has only been ratified by a few states. The EU and its member states often praise themselves for standing up for human rights, pointing the finger at others. The EU states have so far largely failed to recognize the rights of indigenous peoples to self-determination and, in particular, to protect their land from being robbed. This report draws attention to this and calls on the EU and the member states to finally recognize the rights of indigenous peoples to live and possess in a legally binding manner.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Berta Cáceres was murdered in 2016 for leading her community in the fight against the construction of a hydroelectric complex in northwestern Honduras. The project, approved without the consent of the community itself, should have been built on the Gualcarque river, the sacred river of the Lenca people, which constitutes a fundamental water resource for about 600 families living in the rainforest. Two years after this heinous murder, the cases of indiscriminate violence, homicides and evictions of entire indigenous communities continue, in absolute violation of international instruments to protect these populations. And in the defense of environmental rights, as in the defense of human rights, the most exposed are women who, too often, are victims of sexual violence, harassment, extortion and smear campaigns. In the face of such grave human rights violations, the European Union must first of all encourage all Member States and third countries to ratify the Convention on Indigenous and Tribal Peoples, which enshrines the right of indigenous peoples to be consulted when development projects are launched. that have an impact on their territories. It is also essential that the European Union, in its foreign policy, takes into account the situation of indigenous peoples' rights when negotiating trade and cooperation agreements, just as it is essential that the Union invest in public awareness campaigns, outside and inside the European Union, on the problem of land rights and on the role that indigenous peoples play in protecting biodiversity and the environment. Finally, I also thank the rapporteur, Mr Assis, for his work in this report which is so important for the European Union and for the environment in general.

name: Renate WEBER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the report we are discussing today is the result of hard work, compromise and openness towards the need not only to acknowledge, but also to take action in ensuring the protection of the rights of indigenous people. I am pleased to see that we have reached an agreement on so many fundamental actualities related to indigenous peoples: the impact of their lifestyle on environmental sustainability, the preservation of cultural diversity, traditions and languages, the conservation of ecosystems and the fight against deforestation, among many others. But, aside from that, today’s report takes a stance and calls for commitments at EU level, through various existing and potentially new mechanisms, to spare no effort in ensuring that indigenous communities are heard, appreciated and supported in their struggles and endeavours. We speak about mechanisms to support human rights defenders working with indigenous people, coherence between the EU’s trade, development and investment policies and their impact on the rights of indigenous people, the inclusion of these communities when elaborating strategies for tackling climate change, and the development of an EU action plan on responsible business conduct to address the implementation of the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights. I would like specifically to thank the rapporteur for his openness and I hope that we will all vote in favour of this report.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, I had the opportunity, with the rapporteur, to visit indigenous communities in Brazil and to verify, on the ground, the difficulties and attacks that are being made against their most fundamental rights. Many of the food products we consume in the European Union have indigenous blood. What is the occupation of land is done illegally, either by the owners of the agribusiness, or by those who exploit natural resources in an absolutely illegal way, and this translates into the loss of lives. So-called democratic countries, such as those in the European Union, cannot validate these criminal behaviors or the violations of indigenous women, nor the murder of indigenous women, as is the case with Berta Cáceres. That is why I attach importance to the content of this report, when it says that it is not worth everything. We must protect the rights of indigenous peoples, their lands and their communities, but we must also ensure that we do not negotiate trade agreements that, in the end, are signed with the ink that, in fact, is the blood of lost lives. .

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, the draft report is full of good will. The suffering of many indigenous peoples who lose their identity, their history, their territory by being subjected to external or internal economic interests is a real violation of human rights and even a crime. But the imposition of unilateral binding standards applying only to European companies will undoubtedly play into the hands of our international competitors, namely China and the United States. On the other hand, the external interference between national power and local communities could be applied without insight. How can we judge, for example, from Brussels, the relations between the metropolis of Paris and the French overseas? On the other hand, the report is very timid on unbridled free trade, the law of the market often authorizing the destruction of indigenous communities. It is this economic law of a market society that authorizes the law of the strongest. We don't talk about it enough.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Mr President, I am very satisfied that we are discussing today the respect for the human rights of indigenous peoples in the world, because it is true, as was said in our debates before this one, that the situation of these rights is today worse than ten years ago and therefore, in this sense, that there is urgency. This is all the more so because, as the report also mentions, today it is estimated that indigenous peoples represent some 5% of the world's total population. I am therefore, like my political group, in favor of firm action to preserve the rights of these indigenous peoples and to ensure that their traditions and ways of life are perpetuated. What nevertheless strikes me as essential and which has been - I think - left a little in the background in the report, is the importance of concerted action at the international level. Today, different indigenous peoples live in more than 70 countries. It therefore seems to me that simple individual measures by the European Union would not resolve the numerous violations of the rights of indigenous peoples. This is why I consider that our efforts should above all focus on building a real international coalition in favor of the promotion of the rights and cultural traditions of indigenous peoples, because I am not sure whether to impose sanctions unilaterally. at this point could possibly improve something in the lives of these indigenous peoples. So let's make this coalition ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: – Mr President, only last week I had a chance to co—organise in Brussels a photographic exhibition about climate change refugees. The faces, and especially the eyes, went really deep into my emotions, and being a North European MEP, I cannot forget the sight of a dead reindeer; dead due to the effects of climate change and the constantly shrinking herding areas, putting the right of the Sami people to practise their traditional profession into even more jeopardy than it is already.  For me as an MEP, the effects of climate change on the rights of indigenous people are really very close to my heart, because the warming climate is the direct, or indirect, cause of many of the violations against their rights. We need to understand and be aware of that.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: - Mr Chairman! About 370 million indigenous people live in 90 countries. Extremely diverse and using many different languages, these communities are present in all geographic regions and represent around 5,000 different cultures. Unfortunately, these groups also constitute as much as 15% of the human population living in poverty, suffer more from hunger and malnutrition, and have very limited access to basic goods, services and economic resources. The European Consensus on Development, adopted last year, contains an important provision to promote the rights of the most vulnerable, including indigenous peoples. Therefore, actions for the rights of these groups should be better integrated with the development policy of the European Union, especially in the context of the implementation of the sustainable development goals. All actors in development policy, including the European Union and Member States, must strive to adopt all necessary measures to fully recognize the protection and promotion of indigenous peoples' rights, including their access to land, living areas and resources. The Union also has the task of ensuring that all development, investment and trade policies respect the human rights and rights of indigenous peoples.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: - Mr President, briefly, to congratulate the rapporteur and to underline the importance of this discussion, here, in the home of European democracy. The defense of the rights of indigenous peoples is, first and foremost, and, of course, up to the States where their communities are located. Without paternalism, the international community must also frame, in legislative terms, the experience of these communities and the territories they inhabit. International law must be applied, especially when the rights of these peoples are called into question. In this regard, I would like to highlight the importance of ratifying ILO Convention No. 169 on Indigenous and Tribal Peoples, and also awaiting its ratification by the 24 Member States of our Union that have not yet done so. These ratifications seem to me to be fundamental, mainly because they demonstrate that there is global agreement on a wide range of principles and rules on these rights. To conclude, and as President of the Delegation for Relations with Brazil, I would like to welcome the announcement by Pope Francis to convene a Special Assembly of the Synod of Bishops for October next year on “Amazonia: New paths for the Church and towards an integral ecology ”, which aims, among other objectives, to promote a fundamental ethical requirement and a basic commitment to human rights.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I too want to thank the rapporteur, Hon. Assis, for the excellent work done. The history of indigenous peoples is a centuries-old history stained with blood and studded with injustices, abuses, genocides and forced expropriations of their ancestral lands. Indigenous peoples have a unique relationship with the land and the environment in which they live: for these people the land is life and the close relationship that binds them to it and its resources completely transcends the concept of ownership of Western societies. The devastating consequences that the loss of land causes for indigenous peoples are a crime against humanity that is perpetuated under the eyes of national institutions: often the perpetrators of such atrocities are multinational companies and it is not uncommon that they are also involved European multinationals. This Assembly in October 2016 had tried by a very large majority a resolution signed by me, on the subject of human rights violations by multinationals. Among other things, we proposed a series of very concrete measures also in this sector but, after almost two years and countless appeals, the European Commission - and I turn to the Commissioner here - continues to remain totally immobile while the multinationals continue to enrich at the expense of the environment and the fundamental rights of these ancestral peoples.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, according to the UN, indigenous people around the world today are facing greater violation of their rights than was the case 10 years ago. Across the world, the collective and individual rights of indigenous peoples are being violated through discrimination, violence, forced expropriations, land grabbing and evictions. It is therefore welcome that the report calls on the EU and the Member States to adopt all necessary measures for the full recognition and protection of the rights of indigenous peoples and for their prior and informed consultation on all issues affecting them. However, one of the most useful things the EU could do to help the situation of indigenous people is to lead by example: Europe’s autochthonous minorities also suffer from discrimination and denial of rights, and some of them from social exclusion. As a reminder, in the case of my minority, 28 years after the fall of Communism and 11 years after EU accession, properties grabbed by the former regime still have not been restituted to their owners, and some that have been restituted are now being renationalised by the state.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I am pleased that Parliament has taken up the issue of indigenous people’s rights, informed by excellent NGOs such as the Unrepresented Nations and People Organization (UNPO). Having visited Brazilian indigenous communities in the Amazon, I think it is of crucial importance for this Parliament to take into account the rights of indigenous communities in all of its policies. Trade, in particular, offers an opportunity for the EU to build a strong legal framework to stop European companies from violating human rights, in particular the rights of indigenous people. Intercultural dialogue and people-to-people contact are also very important tools to promote mutual understanding and democracy. My Socialist and Democrat colleague, Francisco Assis, has done a brilliant job with this report, giving a good overview of issues faced by indigenous peoples around the world and I am glad to see that land rights are at the heart of the report, as well as a strong focus on gender issues, such as sexual and reproductive health. I am also happy to announce that I will be hosting in the European Parliament a delegation of Kayapo people from Brazil in September.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, land grabbing by indigenous peoples is on the agenda in Asia, Africa and Latin America. There is a systematic expulsion of all indigenous peoples, mainly by multinationals, who appear as so-called investors. We have Chinese, American, but also European multinationals. They are literally seizing the land of the local population and all this is being done under the auspices of the European Union. If we really want to enter a series and stop this situation, we must formulate sanctions, create a black list of companies that seize the land of indigenous peoples and also a black list and a ban on the import of products from these companies which have seized the land of indigenous peoples. There is no other way but this one, to finally put an end to the seizure of the lands of the indigenous peoples.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: - Mr. President, the indigenous leader Lolita Chávez was nominated for the Sakharov Prize and even today she continues to face fear. Two years ago, the defender Berta Cáceres was assassinated. It is said with affection that Berta did not die, that she multiplied. However, in 2017 alone there have been 312 Berta Cáceres. 312 indigenous defenders and leaders assassinated. And the lack of protection and violation of rights is even greater in the case of being a woman. This report on the violation of the rights of indigenous peoples is highly necessary, but it is not enough. You cannot make a statement like this with your left hand and with your right hand continue with trade and investment treaties that enable European transnationals to violate rights and take advantage of the instability that they themselves generate to grab land, promote mining, deforest and kill, ultimately. The architecture of impunity cannot continue to be allowed. It is imperative not to waste time and the European Commission should be fully involved in the legally binding international instrument of the United Nations.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, the seizure of the lands of indigenous peoples is, above all, the tip of the iceberg of a more general phenomenon which has global roots, namely the violation of the human rights of these peoples. These peoples are usually made up of people who do not have the ability to defend themselves, much less to defend their interests. For this reason, they are exploited by multinational corporations, which usually have mercenary armies and exploit these people, not only by plundering their land, not only by exploiting the natural resources of these peoples, but often by using them as slaves. , torturing them and forcing them to leave their homelands. It is an unacceptable situation, a crime against humanity, which the European Union must tackle with concrete action. This is required not only by the principles of the European Union, but also by our culture and humanity.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to say to the Members of this Parliament and the rapporteur Mr Assis that this has been a very useful exchange and I thank all the Members for their interventions. Let me reiterate the high importance that the European Union attaches to the rights and well-being of indigenous peoples – their children, their women and their men – and to stopping the practice of land grabbing. The Commission cooperates with the International Labour Organization on the promotion of Convention 169 and of indigenous peoples’ rights in external relations, and we will also further reflect, as I said in my introduction, on the call for the commitment to launch an action plan on responsible business conduct. Support for indigenous peoples’ rights is integral to the European Union’s human rights policies and today’s discussion on this important, highly complex and pertinent report gives full evidence that this has to stay that way.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: reporter. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by expressing my deep satisfaction at the very broad consensus that has been glimpsed in this chamber on this issue. As the Commissioner has just said, and very well, this is an extremely complex subject. There are no simple solutions to this type of problem. That is why it is important for the European Union to fully assume its responsibilities. In making a commitment to indigenous peoples, we are, above all, resuming a commitment to the best of ourselves. We have a set of values ​​that inspire our action, which are reasonably consensual values. Although we are experiencing difficult times in European political life today, it is good, at other times, to realize that these values ​​continue to be relatively unifying values ​​for Europeans and their political representatives. Respect for human rights and respect for the fundamental principle of human dignity are essential values ​​that must always govern our political intervention, under any circumstances. Afterwards, our policies will be declined differently, depending on the doctrinal and programmatic options of each one, with due respect for their own parliamentary democracies, such as those in which we live. But there is a set of fundamental values ​​that have to be taken care of. Today, when talking about indigenous peoples, we are also talking about these values. We all recognize that indigenous peoples, who in fact make up a significant percentage of humanity, are people particularly affected by situations of violence, oppression and injustice. Often, they are absolutely misunderstood. Perhaps the greatest injustice is to look at them and see in them a kind of anachronism that must be called into question, which must be exterminated. It is often on the basis of this, on the basis that indigenous peoples are anachronistic peoples, that we close our eyes, too often, to many of the violence that is committed on them. Now, the contribution that this European Parliament can and must make - and I am sure it will make it tomorrow, with a very significant vote - is to assume this responsibility on the part of Europeans. Just to finish, allow me just another 30 seconds to say the following. I am aware that this report points out that Europeans are demanded more than other peoples in the world, and the only thing I heard during this debate was that, in doing so, we would be in some way establishing a differentiation that would turn against we. But Europe, to demand responsibility from others, must start by setting an example. It is precisely by giving this example to other peoples and other nations and to other regions of the world that we will be in a better position to participate actively in an international debate that is useful in promoting the rights of indigenous peoples.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Tuesday July 3, 2018.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for the debate on the report by Charles Goerens, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on a Union external strategy to combat early and forced marriage - next steps (2017/2275 (INI)) (A8-0187 / 2018).

name: Charles GOERENS
text: protractor. - Madam President, I have the honor to present to this House a report entitled "Towards an external strategy of the Union to combat early and forced marriage - next steps". The issue that is the subject of our debate today concerns a very large number of people. More than 700 million people around the world are affected by this problem. These are girls and boys, but above all, young girls who are the victims of a practice that is absolutely inhuman and reprehensible. The European Parliament has so far made every effort to condemn these practices. In Sudan, for example, the marriage age is 10 years. From the age of 10, young girls who are forced to marry cannot oppose it and this creates untenable situations. The Belgian daily Le Soir recently recounted the extremely sad story of a girl who was the victim of a forced marriage. What is the role of the European Parliament in this whole issue? We have iteratively thematized, I said, this problem. It is not the number of findings that is lacking. Everything has been said, but perhaps not yet by everyone. What needs to be done is to define a strategy, an approach to move the lines in this area. However, to develop a strategy, we must set a course. Therefore, firstly, one must have a clear vision on the objectives and, second, define the path to get there. We must therefore agree on the appropriate means to be put in place to fight this scourge. The goals are as follows: we want the marriage age to be raised to 18, and not just in one or two countries or even in the European Union, but all over the world. It is a universal standard. It has been consecrated by a number of international texts, it has been consecrated by a number of conventions which have already been ratified or are in the process of being ratified. The minimum age for marriage must be made a legal obligation and this legal obligation becomes an obligation of result. A policy based on results must be initiated. It is not enough to have enshrined in law a ban on marriage below the age of 18, it must be ensured that this obligation becomes reality. Now let's talk about the means. In countries with extreme poverty, education is often the poor relation of public policies. It is in the context of a political dialogue that the Commission and the European External Action Service should address these issues. The Commission and, of course, the Member States, which provide the bulk of the resources made available for development aid policy. We must support institutional actors such as Unicef ​​and Fnuap (United Nations fund for populations) who have considerable experience and expertise in this area. Then, I will also ask the Commission to make the fight against early and forced marriages an element of conditionality. Let's also talk about credibility. We must ensure that all Member States of the European Union also set this standard of marriage at 18 years. We ask the Commission - this is also a request from our committee and from the report that I have the honor to present to you - to devote one of the next years to this issue, by declaring a European year for the fight against forced and early marriage. Finally, it is important to fill the gaps created by the Global gag rule. I know that the Commission is on the right track, it can count on our full support. To conclude, we need a strong and determined European Union, strong partner states, not skimp on resources, set a course and, at the latest, we should have extremely comforting and tangible results in 2030, the year in which the objectives of sustainable development should be realized.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would first like to thank the rapporteur, Charles Goerens, for his excellent report. Protecting girls is, first and foremost, about upholding European values and respect for human rights. It is also about enforcing European law and respecting the Charter of Fundamental Rights and international human rights law. Combating child marriage requires a comprehensive strategy, and the European Union has already stepped up its external work and the recommendations included in the report are of vital importance to us and will help us in achieving even more. Ending child marriage has been identified as a priority for the European Union action plan on human rights and democracy. We have translated this priority through the EU Gender Action Plan (GAP II) with a strong emphasis on the empowerment of girls. The revised European Union guidelines for the promotion and protection of the rights of the child highlight the fact that raising awareness and promoting gender equality is a priority for European engagement with partner countries. The human rights and democracy country strategies for the 2016—2020 period include children’s rights as one of the main priorities, some of them focused on combating child marriage. The report also mentions children on the move as particularly vulnerable. The communication on the protection of children in migration, adopted in April 2017, proposes actions to protect these children, including girls who are at risk of forced marriage. I want to reassure you that early and forced marriage is being regularly raised in political and human rights dialogues with the EU’s partner countries and we will continue to do so, as requested in the report. The report also calls for the Union to work together with the relevant UN agencies – and the rapporteur also requested this here – on this subject. This cooperation is already ongoing and will continue. It has to continue. For instance, the European Union has contributed EUR 6 million to the UNFPA—UNICEF Global Programme to Accelerate Action to End Child Marriage. The programme targets communities from a group of 12 countries and focuses on education, access to health care, strengthening enforcement mechanisms, girls’ empowerment and changing social norms. In September 2017, the European Union and the United Nations launched a historic initiative, branded the ‘Spotlight Initiative’, to end violence against women and girls with an investment of EUR 500 million. Ending early and forced marriage is as much about adopting protective legislation as about enhancing access to education. The report refers many times to the lack of education, not only as a root cause, but also as a consequence of early marriage. We share this view. The communication on education and emergencies and protracted crises, adopted in May 2018, reiterates the protective role of education, recognising that children who are not in school are exposed to forced marriage and early pregnancy, among many other risks. The Union will markedly focus its education in emergency actions to bring children back into school, those forcibly displaced or those belonging to vulnerable and disadvantaged groups and to quality education. We are also doing our homework inside the Union. We are combating early and forced marriage through promoting sustainable social change, through our rights, equality and citizenship programme. The Union has co—financed the setting up of a European network on guardianship for unaccompanied children. This network will allow developing guardianship capacity as well as the prevention of, and responses to, early and forced marriage. In October last year, we had a Girls Summit in Brussels, which brought together many young girls from around the world. The aim was to put the spotlight on what needs to be done to ensure their rights are respected, protected and of course enforced. I would like to conclude by sharing some key messages from this summit that I find very valid in the context of today’s debate. Firstly, child marriage is not only a violation of girls’ rights, but also a form of violence and discrimination against women and girls and, as such, is absolutely unacceptable. Secondly, to end this practice it is of the utmost importance that girls and women have a voice at all levels of society. We therefore very much share the views expressed in the report that the active participation of girls in society is an active way of preventing child marriage. Thirdly, as the report says, it is urgent to inform and educate men and boys. Men and boys must take full responsibility to challenge discriminatory social norms and gender stereotypes and foster positive norms of gender equality, non—violence and respect. Finally, education is the main channel through which sustainable progress in ending child marriage will be achieved. Congratulations again to the rapporteur.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the FEMM Committee, which I represent today as draftsman, has already fought several times to stop the havoc of forced marriages, in particular child marriages that afflict all countries of the world, including Member States of the Union. When I learned of the AFET commission's decision to propose a resolution to the Commission to highlight the problem, I was pleased to hear that our requests, as FEMM commission, have finally been heard. We are no longer alone in fighting this violation of human rights, as can also be seen from the resolution that has been tabled in this House. In fact, from what was highlighted in a recent UNICEF report, if the numbers of this problem continue to grow at the current rate, we could have 1.2 billion child marriages worldwide by 2050. The same report shows how the childhood marriages negatively and permanently affect both the physical and mental health of the victims who, let us remember once again, are only girls. Childhood early forced marriage constitutes a serious violation of human rights and this is enshrined in various international conventions and by the European Union itself, as the report states, as it is itself the main actor in global development and human rights and must perform a leading role in effectively stopping such crimes, especially through the framework of its foreign policy and its development cooperation policies with third countries.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, forced marriages leave an impact on girls and boys, and go against the fundamental rights and the dignity of children. We must be clear in our words: early and forced marriages are a form of violence. We must remember that these kinds of marriage lead to serious consequences, including limiting opportunities to study for those concerned, as education is often ceased abruptly, and, in some cases, to high mortality rates among mothers. We need to ensure that forced marriages are not conducted on European territory among migrants or person of non-European citizenship. If we want to strengthen the fight against these forms of marriage, we need to invest in education and empowerment, especially for women and girls, and provide support to victims. Boys and men in third countries need to be given more information and education in order to develop support for measures that respect human rights, including those of children and women. We need the EU, as an institution which has a global role on human rights, to also take a central role in the fight against early and forced marriages. The EU and its Member States must cooperate with the competent authorities, including those in third countries, and provide training and technical assistance so as to achieve legislation against this practice and ensure it is enforced.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, we all know the story of Noyud Ali, a Yemeni girl divorced at the age of ten. She took advantage of a trip from home, got into a taxi and asked him to take her to court. Before the judge he said: I want a divorce. Noyud married against her will. She was taken by her husband and, that same night, raped by this man, says the girl, who smelled like onion. She asked her mother-in-law for help. That help never came. She started her married life by working in the kitchen during the day and being beaten and raped at night. This is a similar story to the 15 million girls who are forced to marry each year. It's 28 per minute. In 193 countries, 144 do not prohibit child marriage. It is necessary to prohibit and criminalize, it is necessary to educate. It is necessary to know whether prevention programs are effective. Finally, we need to reflect on whether European funding for external action should depend on concrete and measurable measures to combat child marriage. Our message can only be one: child marriage is unacceptable.

name: Baroness Nosheena MOBARIK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, despite considerable progress in advancing gender equality around the world, including through landmark agreements such as the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action, women around the world are still vulnerable to all kinds of abuse, and in too many places their human rights are completely disregarded.  It is cultural norms and practices which allow this. Child early and forced marriage is a cultural, not a religious, practice, and while strict legal enforcement and education may eventually bring about a changed mindset, it will be a slow, gradual progression before we are rid of these practices. And despite there being many international and legal instruments already available to governments to fight these malpractices, we have a long way to go to eliminate child early and forced marriage. Our efforts must continue and be accelerated. I therefore fully support the recommendations made by MEP Goerens in his report.  Much consideration was given to demands for a minimum age of marriage. I accept that in some Member States you can marry at 16 with parental consent. However, I believe it is right we consider a higher age so that vulnerable young people, particularly girls, are sufficiently mature and are able to stand up for their rights and resist social pressure.  The ECR is committed to gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls through different means, focusing on achieving protection for women and girls from physical and sexual violence, as well as giving them opportunities in education, employment and in society in general.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, in the space of a few months we will return to the issue of forced marriages in this Parliament, a practice that we must remember that also occurs in the European Union and the United States. As we have already mentioned more than once, the protection of minors is in our treaties, and our foreign policy must strictly follow these rules. Once again, we call for coherence, for the effective application of international standards and agreements, such as the Istanbul Convention and the United Nations 2030 Agenda, as our development policies in third countries and trade policies converge towards respect for human rights, especially of women, girls and boys. Therefore, we are voting in favor of this report. We are in favor of the eradication of early marriage also here, in the European Union, and in any part of the world, because they are practices that involve forms of slavery that still persist in this world. In this way, we will also be complying with article 37 of the Istanbul Convention. Zero tolerance, Commissioner, to any type of imposition of a patriarchal culture.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! Child and forced marriages have become a problem with the massive migration of recent years in Europe. Young women in particular are often only 12 or 13 years old. At this age, there can be no question of a voluntary, conscious decision to marry. How should we handle this? Should we recognize such marriages as rights from another cultural area? No never! Because there can be no question of a voluntary marriage. I experienced this myself with an African woman who was married to a man of about 60 when she was 14 and who very soon had a daughter. She wanted to flee from this marriage and was threatened with death by both her husband and the family for bringing shame on the family. That is why I am glad that in the new resolution that I worked on we are calling for: In Europe, marriages should only be recognized if both partners are over 18 years old. Unfortunately, that's not a law. The EU can only make one recommendation to the Member States. Even so, it has become more likely that both spouses will enter into the relationship willingly and consciously, and that their children will receive adequate upbringing from adult parents. The resolution also contains a recommendation to the Member States to give women a residence permit which is independent of that of their husbands. Actually a matter of course, but still often not fulfilled.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President! Medieval forced and child marriages had long since been overcome here. Ms. Merkel's uncontrolled mass immigration has brought her to Europe thousands of times. We do not want this form of violence against minors. It brings immeasurable suffering. But this is the order of the day in parallel societies. The cause of this practice is - let's call the evil by its name - the Sharia. The causes of forced and child marriages are not poverty and patriarchy, but primarily Islam. The report misses the chance to make this clear. It is right to counteract forced and child marriages in foreign policy. But we have to sanction these crimes here too. Marrying a nine-year-old is child abuse, nothing else. Anyone who does this must be prosecuted. Contrary to what the report claims, not only men are responsible for this, women too, and mothers actively participate in the forced marriages of their children. All of this has to stop. We have to set clear legal limits to this.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President! If the rapporteur describes early and forced marriage as violations of human rights and exploitation, one can only agree with him. Unfortunately, the demand for ratification of various conventions such as the Istanbul Convention is not the solution to this problem. The example of Turkey clearly shows: Although forced marriages are officially prohibited there, Islamic-religious marriage from twelve onwards is not. Twelve-year-old girls are often faced with the choice between a forced marriage or being rejected by the family. According to Unicef, almost every third woman in Turkey is less than eighteen years old. The sociologist Necla Kelek, who was born in Istanbul, estimates that there were around 500 forced marriages in Berlin in 2017 and is of the opinion that the tradition of forced marriage is becoming part of everyday life here too. We must therefore not turn a blind eye in the Union. Because while we are discussing and addressing this problem, an Islamic parallel world is escalating among us, in which Sharia-based injustice against minors is actually lived out.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: - Madam President, child marriage is obviously a violation of human rights.The question is how Europe can help remedy this.Perhaps we should question our own foreign policies.I note with great bitterness that in our various agreements, there are never, or very rarely, chapters highlighting equality between women and men, children's rights, etc.I can assure you, however, that here, during our last session under the partnership agreement with Chile, we finally for the first time, inscribed a chapter on equality between men and women.It is thanks to the generalization of this type of conditionality that Europe will be able to help put an end to it.The problem will not be eradicated overnight, but this is the way to go.This is the way to go.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Madam President! Ladies and gentlemen, We are talking about the issue of external marriages as part of the European Union's external policy, and yet even in this House we hear that it is a problem that exists here in Europe - not in countries that do not accept the Istanbul gender convention, but in countries that have adopted it . Therefore, ladies and gentlemen, it is not postulates that are important, but decisive actions. The International Convention on the Rights of the Family, the draft of which we propose in Poland, assumes the nullity of any forced marriage, wherever it is concluded. One more comment about this particular text - the word Islam is never mentioned in this text, while the United States is attacked three times. For what? For the policy of defending the weakest in the refusal to finance international abortion organizations. Let's think about the moral foundations on which our policy stands, because their lack is the main source of the problems we are dealing with.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Madam President, knowing that child early and forced marriages, despite being a clear violation of human rights, are still ingrained in some cultures and traditions, the European Union’s external strategy against them should have as central points education and cooperation with communities. Involving and educating community leaders, especially women, is fundamental in changing attitudes and behaviour concerning child marriages. Education plays an essential role in order to foster social change and empower women and girls so that they can escape from discrimination and from decisions which they do not take and so they can fulfil their potential. Increasing the number of women in decision-making positions can help promote prevention and eradication policies for combating all kinds of violence against women, including forced and child marriages. However, we should not forget that the role of men is key in addressing gender stereotypes. Therefore, fighting against child and forced marriages involves fighting against patriarchal societies.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, early and forced child marriages constitute one of the most serious violations of human rights and often cause long-term damage to the physical and mental health of the victims of this practice. The phenomenon, sanctioned by the Istanbul Convention, does not only affect third countries but is also on the rise in Europe: according to UNICEF data, today in fact, 750 million women in the world have married before the age of eighteen. The European Union cannot remain indifferent to this practice, which still today deprives too many girls of the essential rights of childhood and of a serene psychophysical growth. To put an end to the phenomenon, both inside and outside the Union, it is necessary in the meantime that the minimum age for marrying at eighteen is uniformly set in the Member States and that administrative, legal and financial measures are adopted to ensure its effective application . But to eradicate the deepest causes of this phenomenon in third countries, it is also necessary to invest in awareness-raising, education and gender equality actions.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Distinguished Chairperson, early forced marriages are a gross violation of the human rights of children and minors.Any strategy against such forms of sexual and domestic violence that seeks to be credible must imply zero tolerance for such practices on European soil.I support the rapporteur's call on Member States that tolerate marriages of minors to set a single age of 18 as the minimum age for marriage.Any coercion should be condemned and prevented, but even when it comes to the voluntary marriage of a minor, I think it is a bad thing.To take on the responsibilities and obligations that marriage brings with it requires a dose of physical and mental maturity that minors in many cases do not have.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the plight of child brides is still a plague that transcends countries, cultures and religions. A drama that always has a common denominator, which has its roots in poverty, in gender inequality, in the lack of education, social and economic opportunities. Forced and early child marriage never offers protection to minors forced to contract it: on the contrary, it constitutes a grave violation of human rights, especially women's rights. It is we, the European Union, as the main actor in the global development of human rights, who must play a leading role in eliminating this unprecedented form of violence against women. We therefore work to create a space for respectful dialogue with community leaders in third countries, to promote cross-cutting and governmental legal, social and diplomatic actions aimed at preventing forced marriages. We demonstrate our leadership in promoting women's rights and human rights.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteurs and congratulate them on the excellent report. Secondly, I would like to thank Commissioner Thyssen and the Commission for a very clear answer and for their activities in this field. This problem of forced – and unforced – marriages of underage girls and boys shows clearly that we need full competence of the Commission in the field of constitutional rights, because if we do not have effective tools, both to address violence against women and girls in our own Member States and to act on a strong basis in our third-country cooperation, we cannot be as effective as we should be. Secondly, I hope that, in our development cooperation and bilateral cooperation, we can increase substantially our aid for education on sexual and reproductive rights for girls, because this is an area in which, globally, aid has been cut the most.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: – Madam President, every seven seconds there is a girl under 15 years old getting married in the world, often to a man much older than herself. Early and forced marriages seriously violate human rights and, often, girls’ rights to education, increase the likelihood of domestic violence and have serious consequences on the sexual and reproductive health of women and girls. Early and forced marriages exist in both third countries and within the EU. Some Member States have laws allowing children younger than 18 to marry under certain circumstances. In the current refugee crisis, it happens along the migration routes and in refugee camps. We should make legislative efforts to end early and forced marriages, at both EU and Member State level. Therefore all Member States should accelerate the ratification of the Istanbul Convention and see that it is fully implemented without delay.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, forced marriages are multiplying in the United States and especially in the European Union, and this is because now, with the mass migration of populations here in the European Union, there are populations with specific cultural backgrounds, but of course with religious roots and references to Islam itself is now forcing forced marriages - a situation that violates human rights, a situation that violates the rights of children, and this process must be banned immediately. Of course, the Istanbul Convention, the UN Convention on the Protection of the Rights of the Child, is also being violated. So we have to have legislation in the European Union to ban forced marriages - they are said to be forced, but they are forced in practice because they are imposed - and of course to invest money in countries that follow this phenomenon, in order to support cultural level and, above all, to pass the views that must apply.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - Madam President, to date, more than 750 million women have been married before the age of 18 and 250 million of them have been married before the age of 15. These are really scary figures that demonstrate serious human rights violations. The problem, however, is that a legal ban on child marriages, early marriages and forced marriages would not in itself guarantee the end of these marriages. We need the widest possible international cooperation to witness the end of this shameful practice. The EU should now push for 18 years to be clearly enacted as a uniform minimum age for marriage, both in the Member States of the European Union and in third countries. I believe that it is the duty of the European Union to clearly condemn these marriages and to act uncompromisingly in this regard, both in the EU and internationally. We in the European Union also have enough tools to influence third countries, so let us do the same in this matter.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, when we hear about forced marriages, we are led to believe that it is something remote in time and space. Sadly, this is more of a topical problem than ever. What is sadder is that it is a very serious violation of human rights which sometimes takes place right before our very eyes, here in Europe. Some newspapers, for example, have also denounced its presence in one of the cities where I grew up, in Palermo, where teenagers between 13 and 17 years old, mainly from Bangladesh, Pakistan, India and Sri Lanka, have literally disappeared from school, overnight, to be sent back by their families to their countries of origin, and there to marry the man who had been jumping for them and whom they had never seen. This shows that the fight against forced marriages must be fought on all fronts, inside and outside the European territory, and by institutions at all levels, starting with those who negotiate trade treaties with these countries and have the duty to condition any benefit on the achievement of minimum standards in this very important sector.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Madam President, the obligation imposed by some African and Asian countries, mainly Islamic ones, on girls to marry at a young age, I would say a child, is a real stigma for modern civilized society and humanity. It is not just a violation of human rights, it is not just violence, it is even worse, it is a brutal and barbaric violation of human nature. Girls whose bodies and bodies have not yet been formed are forced to behave like adults. No matter what legal measures we take, no matter what recommendations we make, we will never be able to heal the physical and especially the psychological challenges and blows that have been created in the hearts of these children. The European Union must act effectively, it must review relations with countries that apply this anachronistic method and, above all, it must not allow this situation to arise in its own region.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, I think we all see forced marriages as a trampling on human rights and human dignity. We are learning about the increase in forced marriages, especially in countries where there is now a war and a humanitarian crisis. For example, we know that in Syria before the war, there were about 13% of these marriages, and this percentage has recently risen to 40%. What is the reason? Forced marriages are caused by a long tradition, partly religious, but also by living conditions. Parents consider the marriage of their children, especially daughters, to be a solution to difficult social conditions or a way to protect against even worse forms of violence. For many girls, this means leaving school, domestic violence, mental health problems and other complications, such as childbirth. However, customs and circumstances may be stronger than the law, and even where these marriages have been prohibited by law, their number has decreased only minimally. This means more education and better living conditions are the solution.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, child, early and forced marriages are a form of gender-based violence and a violation of the rights of the child. Apart from direct psychological and physical consequences, early and forced marriages have a dramatic negative effect on a child’s right to education. As a feminist and a children’s rights campaigner, I fully support the report’s call for all Member States to ratify the Istanbul Convention, which is the most comprehensive legal instrument that we have to combat all forms of gender-based violence. Eleven Member States, including the UK, still have not ratified this Convention. Shame on them! Regarding neighbouring countries, let’s recall that, in autumn 2016, President Erdogan’s ruling AKP party in Turkey tried to introduce a law that would have allowed convicted rapists to marry their child victims, thereby legalising paedophilia. And shame on Theresa May for entertaining such an appalling regime during a recent state visit to the UK! Thank goodness for the values and decency of the EU, which stands against all forms of violence against women and girls.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I was delighted with this debate this evening because all sides of the House emphasised the absolute horror of forced marriages. Only yesterday I was reading about an 11-year-old girl who was forced to marry a 51-year-old man. And when you think of the fact that, even for ourselves, if we have to spend half an hour or an hour with people we do not get on well with, it can be trying, can you imagine what it is like for a young girl forced, as MEPs mentioned, to become an adult almost overnight and, at the same time, only a child? It’s horrible and it’s a cultural, religious – call it what you like – phenomenon that has been going on for too long. We really have to ensure, first of all, that we end any such practices that may be happening in Europe, and do everything we can to end them internationally, because this is an absolute scandal in the modern era. Every child is entitled to a life and every girl should be able to grow up and marry in her own time.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, from this debate I conclude that we all share a common interest in using European diplomatic power, and all European instruments to their full potential, to protect girls from early and forced marriage. We now have a unique opportunity with Agenda 2030 for Sustainable Development and its specific target 5.3 on child marriage. To succeed and meet the 2030 Agenda target, we need a stronger partnership, we need more and better laws, more action plans, budget and accountability mechanisms and more data collection. We also need to see more comprehensive approaches, addressing all the various patterns behind child marriage. We need, too, more communication of positive stories on what works and also on what does not work. We see great potential in a European year dedicated to the fight against child, early and forced marriages, and we will ask our services to evaluate this idea. What is absolutely necessary and clear is that we need more funding. An urgent scaling-up is required as current investments are not enough. Lastly, we need more long-term commitment. We are talking here about the devastating consequences of child marriage on the lifetime of girls and on society. Let me thank the honourable Members for this useful exchange and specifically the rapporteur for his good report.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: protractor. - Madam President, first of all, I am extremely satisfied with the quality of this discussion, as the Commissioner has just rightly pointed out, whom I thank for her absolutely relevant and very appropriate words and comments. It thus testifies to the will of the Commission to tackle this problem head on, and we have taken care to give political impetus to this problem. Then the Member States of the European Union must be exemplary. They must include permission to marry at age 18 in their legislation. This is an obligation of result, no mitigating circumstances allow this obligation to be ignored. In addition, the anchoring of a criminal practice that recurs from year to year, from generation to generation, in no way justifies its maintenance. Again, there are no extenuating circumstances to excuse or justify in any way the perpetuation of a practice which is absolutely villainous and criminal. It is not the anchoring of such a practice in religion or in the cultural tradition that would justify it, because in a pinch we should end up accepting cannibalism on the grounds that this practice too has been anchored in certain traditions. . So let's be absolutely clear so that there is not the slightest misunderstanding about this, we as the European Union, as Member States of the European Union, we must be absolutely determined to show the right example and make it an element of conditionality in our external relations. Let no one come and tell us that this ban would fall under a jurisdiction or a set of behaviors of Western countries. The universal convention of human rights is universal. All legislation on the protection of the rights of the child is universal. So I believe we need to act globally. As the Commission embraces the will to influence the rest of the world, I believe that we cannot ignore this point. Finally, I would have liked to see the Commission take a decision on our request to devote one of the next years to this issue. I know we are in competition with others, however, given the scale that this problem has grown and the additional scope it may have in the future, given the strong population growth in some. country, I believe that declaring a European year for the fight against forced marriages and the marriages of minors would be entirely up to our ambitions.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Wednesday, July 4, 2018. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: written. - Europe will not be built on the basis of weak values ​​that, under the guise of respect for cultural and religious diversity, accommodate harmful traditions that damage human dignity and are a serious obstacle to development. Through its external strategy against early and forced marriages, the Union reaffirms its commitment to universal values, despite recognizing that the mere legal prohibition of forced marriages does not by itself guarantee the end of these practices, due to the complexity of the social, political, ecological and economic factors involved. I want to underline that although these practices disproportionately affect girls around the world, boys are also victims, as the report acknowledges: to date, 750 million girls and 156 million boys have been married before their 18th birthday, while 250 million girls and 25 million boys did so before the age of 15. The celebration of child marriages violates the declarations on the rights of the child, the Istanbul Convention to combat violence against women, and European traditions that safeguard the free consent of the spouses. The Union must affirm respect for this value inside and outside its borders.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - Child marriage is a global problem that transcends countries, cultures and religions. The numbers are facts: today there are more than 750 million women in the world who are married before the age of 18.
