Early and forced marriages have extremely negative consequences on the physical and mental health and personal development of the persons concerned as well as on children born in such marriages and society as a whole. I fully support this Report towards the EU's external strategy against early and forced marriages - the next steps, given that the eradication of these practices, which constitute serious violations of human rights, equality, independence and physical integrity, has been identified as one of the external priorities. EU action in the field of the promotion of women's rights and human rights. This report, which I support, notes that some EU Member States allow marriage at the age of 16 with parental consent, and therefore calls on legislators, both in EU countries and in third countries, to set a single age of 18 as the minimum age. for marriage and to introduce the necessary administrative, judicial and financial measures to enforce this requirement, for example by promoting the registration of marriages and births and ensuring that girls have access to institutional support mechanisms, including psychosocial counseling, safeguards and economic empowerment opportunities.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: in writing. - Child and forced marriages are unfortunately still present in different parts of the world. It can be stated that child marriage is a global problem that transcends countries, cultures and religions. To date, more than 750 million girls have been married before the age of 18, including 250 million girls before the age of 15, a significant increase in times of instability, migration crisis, armed conflict, and natural and humanitarian disasters. Although most countries set a minimum age for marriage, which is usually 18, many countries still provide exceptions to the minimum age for marriage. Brides and grooms are often victims of violence, suffer from a number of health problems, are deprived of education and future paid employment, are placed in a dependent relationship, and are therefore more likely to become and remain poor, so that poverty continues to be inherited. According to research, child marriage will cost trillions of dollars to developing countries by 2030. Addressing the problem requires a holistic and comprehensive approach, addressing the root causes and extending gender equality to all policy areas beyond education and health, which are traditional sectors. Child, early and forced marriages are a clear violation of children’s rights and a form of violence against girls and boys that must be tackled globally.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: written. - A few decades ago, forced marriages were called marriages that couples considered best to enter into because a woman had become pregnant. Today, forced marriages refer to marriages in which very young girls, sometimes even infants, are forced or pressured. Child and forced marriages are a serious violation of fundamental human rights. In addition, children's health is endangered by pregnancy and childbirth. Child marriages are prohibited by a number of international agreements, such as the Istanbul Convention, but concrete action is still urgently needed. In Finland, child marriages sparked a stir when PLAN International's fundraising campaign appeared on the street a year ago, featuring a 12-year-old girl who was recently pregnant. The picture spoke more than a thousand words and sparked heated debates, which I think is merely a good thing. The problems do not go away by silencing them. As a result of immigration in particular, childbirths have also increased within EU countries. The numbers of child marriages are appalling. An estimated four million girls marry before the age of 15 each year. If the situation continues, it is estimated that by 2050 there will be 1.2 billion victims of child marriage in the world. This development must end. The root causes of child and forced marriages, such as harmful practices and habits, extreme gender inequality, poverty and lack of education, need to be addressed. No reasons based on religion or custom must take precedence over children's rights. Children must be allowed to live their lives without external coercion or pressure to marry.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Arne Lietz and Jo Leinen, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on climate diplomacy (2017/2272 (INI) (A8-0221 / 2018).

name: Arne LIETZ
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, dear representatives of the Commission. I am very pleased that we are discussing the own-initiative report on climate diplomacy by the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Committee on the Environment here in plenary today. We have drawn up a very comprehensive text and, above all, I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs who have contributed to the success of this paper over the past few weeks for the excellent intergroup cooperation. It was time for the European Parliament to put climate diplomacy on its external agenda. However, if the EU is to make a credible international commitment to the implementation of the climate goals from the Paris Agreement, it must first of all do its own homework. European climate policy must be ambitious, and it must be visibly based on its own commitments and promises and make a significant contribution to supporting less affluent countries in implementing international climate norms. In order to put the EU in a position to take a leading role in the international implementation of the climate goals of the Paris Agreement, we must first strengthen the European External Action Service in the field of climate diplomacy in terms of personnel and finances. This also includes enabling the EU delegations in third countries to integrate the topic more closely into their portfolio. This replacement must also be reflected in the EU's next multiannual financial framework. Against this background, I appeal to the European Commission to comply with the demands formulated in the report and to strengthen EU climate diplomacy in a sustainable manner, also to continue to actively involve it in the upcoming legislative initiatives. The European Parliament must also firmly establish climate diplomacy on its foreign policy agenda. In view of the cross-departmental nature of the topic, Parliament's climate diplomatic approach must also include other policy areas. In particular, conflict prevention, migration policy, trade policy and the common security and defense policy are part of it. That would be a direct approach and the application of the development policy goals 2030, the goals for sustainable development, which can and must be well connected here. In view of the fact that climate change and its consequences are not only a concern for politics, I am particularly pleased that Pope Francis 'encyclical “Laudato si'”, which also makes a strong reference to the topic, has been included in the report as a reference point. As a further practical example, I would like to use trade policy, which will also be used in future agreements and in other policy areas, but also in trade policy and free trade agreements. We experienced that at CETA and now with the currently negotiated free trade agreement with Japan. Via its parliamentary networks, its delegations in partner countries and through delegation trips, the European Parliament must further advance its climate policy agenda and, in its diplomatic efforts, set the climate goals as part of the sustainable development goals as an integral part of bilateral and unilateral talks. The European Commission and the European External Action Service should work closely with the European Parliament and the Member States to develop a strategy for EU climate diplomacy. Their implementation and revision must be checked regularly. In doing so, Parliament will have the task of identifying successes and gaps in the EU's climate diplomatic efforts in its relevant reports and of making suggestions for future directions. In addition to international summits such as the G7 and G20, the regional level is becoming increasingly important for successful climate policy. Cities and regions, local actors up to town halls are often the decisive actors in the implementation of climate policy demands and the sustainable agenda. They should therefore be included in the EU's climate diplomatic guidelines and taken into account, even when the EU is on the move around the world. The same applies to civil society and science. These networks are particularly important for high-profile campaigns and international persuasion. In conclusion, I would like to once again thank my co-rapporteur, Jo Leinen, for the great cooperation, but also the committee secretariats, also for the hearing that we held, and I am now looking forward to a productive debate.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, Commissioner Arias Cañete, ladies and gentlemen! Climate protection is a global challenge and it can only be tackled through global cooperation. The EU is of course a pioneer in climate protection and has so far achieved many achievements. But Europe alone cannot protect the climate. We need partners in the world, and as we know we need all levels. We need the governments, but we also need civil society, the local level, the regional level, companies and science. That is precisely the subject of our report: how we can develop an instrument - together with all the institutions that the EU has, not just the Commission, not just the Council, but also Parliament and our agencies - how we can be coherent, strategic and can also credibly promote the implementation of the Paris Agreement. Mr Lietz has already mentioned: We want EU policy to become coherent when it comes to climate protection, that is: mainstreaming into all other policy areas, above all, of course, into trade policy, development policy and security policy. And there would be my first question to Commissioner Arias Cañete: can you imagine that the trade agreements we make are conditioned and that the countries with which we make agreements have ratified and are implementing the Paris Agreement? We see that countries that do not do that gain advantages that are unfair. We recently had this big conference on the relationship between climate change and security policy. Indeed: water shortages, droughts, storms, massive rainfall can endanger the existence of millions of people and thus also endanger security, which we have already observed in some countries. The EU's foreign and security policy should adapt to the fact that we have early warning systems and that we also base our strategies on them. There is an example of strategic partnerships, Commissioner: we have been working with China for many years on an emissions trading system - that is certainly a success story - and I would also think that we are doing thematic cooperation with other countries, especially when we exit fossil energies, in the development of renewable energies and other policies that we need for climate protection. There is also a question for Mr Arias Cañete: How far has the Commission done so that we can do thematic cooperation with cities, regions and other countries? We of course need a credible climate policy with us. Katowice will be the next test case. We believe that the EU should raise its climate target for 2030. I also have a question for Commissioner Arias Cañete: is it possible that before Katowice we will be able to increase the already agreed target of 40% CO2 reduction - in the light of the legislation that we have already passed? It would certainly be gratifying if we would also present the long-term strategy to 2050 after Katowice to ourselves and to our partners around the world. I too was delighted with this report as I was working. Thank you, Arne Lietz, who was the main driver. It was his idea, the cooperation between AFET and ENVI here in Parliament shows that this is possible. I would also like to thank all the departments in Parliament for their work. I am looking forward to broad support in the plenary tomorrow, and then the work really starts.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, let me begin by congratulating the co-rapporteurs, Mr Lietz and Mr Leinen, for their excellent work and their cooperation on this important issue, particularly as we look in the months ahead towards COP24 in Katowice. The Commission fully shares Parliament’s view that addressing climate change is a collective responsibility at global level and requires a continuing shared commitment to multilateralism. Today, more than ever, Europe stands by the principles of a rules-based order, with the Paris Agreement as a cornerstone of an indispensable multilateral system. For Europe, dealing with climate change is not only a matter of political responsibility and multilateral engagement but also a matter of security, prevention of conflict, and stability around the world. Those principles were reaffirmed during the second edition of the Ministerial on Climate Action, co-hosted by the European Union, together with China and Canada, in Brussels on 20 and 21 June. Ministers confirmed that the Paris Agreement is irreversible and it is not to be renegotiated, stressing the importance of multilateralism. They reiterated their commitment to concluding the negotiations on the Paris Agreement work programme. In addition, on 22 June, High Representative and Commission Vice-President Mogherini hosted an important event on climate, peace and security, at which, as a European Union leader, she was both congratulated and further called upon by international leaders. The European External Action Service and the Commission are committed to deploying maximum political and diplomatic efforts to integrate action on climate, security and development, enhancing the European Union’s already strong, proactive voice on the global stage. As acknowledged in your report, 2018 is a crucial year for international climate action. The European Union is taking an active role in the Talanoa Dialogue. The recent ‘EU for Talanoa’ conference gathered some 550 participants, with widespread agreement that concluding on the Paris work programme at COP24 will be an important stepping stone towards delivering the Paris Agreement commitments. Talanoa is also the theme of the European Union climate diplomacy weeks in 2018 and presents an opportunity for the Union to showcase its model for low-emissions transition in a way that empowers more ambitious engagement from state and non-state players in order to help our partner countries implement the Paris Agreement. In this context, the European Union recently launched a strategic partnership for the implementation of the Paris Agreement. This is but one of the several initiatives on climate change that the Union is carrying out in various regions of the world through its sustainable development and cooperation instruments. A number of those initiatives, such as the global climate-change alliances, help address trans-boundary climate-related issues through dialogue and negotiation, thus supporting the climate diplomacy objectives. The report also rightly acknowledges that climate diplomacy plays a vital role in global security. Climate security has become one of the most important parts of our climate diplomacy, and the need to strengthen our efforts, to avoid climate change becoming a serious threat multiplier, is widely understood in our partner countries. The Commission welcomes the recognition in the report that effective climate diplomacy requires leadership at home as well as action at international level. The European Union is continuing to lead by example, by forging ahead with implementation of our nationally determined contributions (NDCs). We all reached a political agreement on the key pillars of the 23rd Climate and Energy Framework and this will allow the European Union to reach beyond our, at least 40%, emission-reduction contribution under the Paris Agreement. The European Union is committed to continuing its efforts. As a next step, the Commission will put forward a vision for the European Union long-term greenhouse emissions reduction strategy by November 2018. It will provide a clear vision of how to have a truly decarbonised European economy and will give a clear direction of travel, to ensure we have the right investments in place. The European Union and its Member States also continue to contribute their fair share to climate finance, remaining the largest donor of public climate finance by population: EUR 20.2 billion to climate action in developing countries in 2016. During this year’s climate diplomacy weeks, the European Union’s delegations around the world will, together with Member States’ embassies, be communicating their success stories. They will be showcasing the European Union’s strong track record in domestic implementation through effective climate policies. The European Union will, through strength and cooperation, build strong partnerships and provide continuous support to the poorest and most vulnerable. President, honourable Members, let me conclude by thanking Parliament once again for this comprehensive report and for your strong support for European climate action. I look forward to continuing to work with you in the months ahead as we approach COP24.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, the debate we have today is more important than it may seem and, therefore, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteurs and also the other committees involved for their work. The fight against climate change that the European Union has led since before the great COP21 agreement is impossible to achieve if we are not able to involve everyone - and you know this very well, Commissioner, who was talking about multilateralism right now. It will be of little use if in Europe we equip ourselves with a strategy to fight against plastic spillage if we are not able to explain its need and force joint responsibility from the rest of the global players. We must be key in the fight against climate change ―as I say― and also be able to understand that this will not be a fight that we win alone, but with the international community at all levels, because it is a problem that affects us all . There will be no country in the world that will not be affected by climate change or anyone who solves it alone, neither the most developed nor the least, but we must also be aware that the damages of climate change will affect the people of the countries the most. that they have no means at their disposal to alleviate the effects of climate change. For months now - and I am ending -, right here in Strasbourg, we received the President of the Marshall Islands, who reminded us that we are a benchmark for the world in this fight. But she especially she told us that, in countries like hers, with an average height of two meters above sea level, there is nowhere to hide. For thousands of people, coping with climate change means the difference between living, fleeing or dying.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, thank you, Mr Leinen, for this report, which calls for the European Union to act as a world leader in reaching the Paris Agreement. I want to emphasize two ideas. Fundamentally, all the policies with an external dimension of the European Union should include climate issues on its agenda and have economic and human support. Mr Arias Cañete mentioned this, but I also want to emphasize the need to take into account that there are particularly vulnerable areas, such as the south of the European continent. And I want, therefore, to vindicate the example of the PRIMA project, funded by Horizon 2020, which comes to promote research and innovation in the Mediterranean basin, in southern Europe, with North Africa. Initiatives like this must also have an example in Horizon Europe, which will thus strengthen its commitment to climate change. I therefore welcome this own-initiative report and hope that climate diplomacy will be reflected in all the policies of the European Union and especially in the support and introduction of technological advances to combat climate change.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President! When I hear voices saying that the European Union should lead the implementation of the Paris Agreement, I am amazed, because in the ENVI Committee and here in the European Parliament you often say in your statements that the Paris Agreement is not ambitious enough, that Parliament should still be more ambitious. Let me remind you that the Paris Agreement came about because its final shape did not include decarbonization, but the importance of the forest in absorbing global CO2 emissions. And the Paris Agreement was undoubtedly a success. It would be good for the European Parliament to focus on filling the Paris Agreement with content, and not put itself in the position of a lone long-distance runner who is de facto running on the wall. It is completely incomprehensible why you propose the introduction of the concept of "climate refugee". The introduction of such regulations will intensify the migration crisis even more. Therefore, I am appealing for caution.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. - (FI) Mr President, European foreign and security policy must have a much stronger climate dimension. We are all pleased with the Paris Climate Agreement and the fact that the European Union was a strong player in it. But not one Paris climate agreement is enough: the climate dimension must be included in all EU bilateral and multilateral discussions and agreements between third countries, and in all bilateral discussions as well. In relations with third countries and in future trade agreements, commitment to the objectives of the Paris Agreement must be required. The essence of this report is therefore that we do not consider this Paris Climate Agreement to be sufficient, but that practical agreements must be made to implement it. We cannot turn a blind eye to cooperation between climate and migration. To this end, efforts must be made to establish, in conjunction with the UN and within the UN framework, a generally accepted definition of climate refugees. In fact, it is rather strange that even today there is no common global definition of what we mean by climate refugees. The EU must play an active role in initiating and defining such negotiations within the UN framework.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, climate change does not need simply to be on the international agenda.  It needs to be the agenda. With the US Trump withdrawal from the Paris Agreement, the EU and Member States must lead by example. They must be the source of strong ambition and fully implement climate policy in their own countries to achieve both the Paris and EU targets. I’m glad that this report acknowledges that a strong external leadership role requires full implementation of ambitious climate policy within the EU, given that countries like Ireland are miserably off track on reaching EU climate targets. Climate change is not some abstract, apocalyptic policy area. It is a present-day reality, affecting the lives of hundreds of thousands of people worldwide. We do need an international legal definition of climate refugee and maybe those who are so vocal against refugees would better serve their agenda by being the most ambitious on climate change. The time for excuses is over. We need a human-rights based climate policy and we need legislators to lead.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, when you start reading the text of this resolution, a series of high-sounding names immediately appear: the United Nations agenda on sustainable development, the Kyoto protocol, the Paris climate agreement: all high-sounding names for one big failure. We believe that these names need to be changed; perhaps we should only admit that there is a big problem, namely that climate change depends on the exploitation and consumption of fossil resources, of fossil fuels: oil, gas and coal. And not only from climate change but also from the political instability of African countries, from their poverty and therefore from migratory flows and therefore also the thousands of premature deaths. So, if we really want to fight climate change, let's stop being virtuosos in Europe and then colonialists in Africa. If we really want to fight global warming, we prevent countries like France from exploiting African resources because then we are all paying the price.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: - Madam President! The resolution is a manifestation of pride - the belief that all minds have been eaten up on the issue on which scientists are arguing, because what the red-and-green ideologists stubbornly refuse here is to acknowledge that the matter is in dispute. Many scientists question the extent and causes of these climate change, much less its ability to prevent it. Worse still, Parliament is about to maneuver the climate with measures that have failed it in all other areas, such as subsidies, regulations, arbitrarily choosing some solutions it deems best, delivering prophecies thirty years ahead, what will it be? in 2050, lecture, printing reams of paper with your documents. This is exactly the opposite way to go. We need to fairly blame people for the costs of using the environment, and look at what technology allows them to avoid paying for it. A spectacular example of how not to fight the climate is the idea of ​​a climate refugee, which will make people willing to apply for this role and possibly even destroy their environment just to get hold of it.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: - (FI) Mr President, although the European Union has been at the forefront of climate policy globally, it has itself seriously underestimated the measures needed. I believe that our current climate package lacks about half of the effective measures we would need to stop global warming below 1.5 degrees. That is why climate policy must be brought into all EU diplomacy and foreign policy. EU-Asia cooperation is a very promising area, as we know from China cooperation. In the G7 / G20 agenda, climate policy must be the EU's number one priority. It must be in all development cooperation agreements and, above all, in trade agreements, and it also means that, in the case of existing agreements, such as CETA, this should be revisited. This also applies, for example, to food and the future Mercosur agreement. It also concerns what kind of products are brought into the EU and how climate compensation or quality standards are made here, and how the EU works within the WTO so that climate and resource efficiency criteria are actually included in international trade agreements and interpretations. Then environmental dumping is also unfair competition, which allows other Member States to sue their partners for incompatible subsidies, for example through the WTO. This is all we need and quite a lot more.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, today there is a very broad consensus on the idea that the issue of climate change is one of the main problems facing humanity and that it can only be resolved through a global response. Now, this leads, from the outset, that the various political actors, the various States or the various supranational entities have an obligation to develop intense diplomatic activity to ensure articulation in the responses to this problem. The European Union has been standing out, worldwide, for the way it has followed this issue and has tried to find solutions, with a view to its resolution. It is clear that it is a complex issue, it is not susceptible to an immediate resolution, but above all it is a topic that can only be dealt with properly if there is an articulation of policies at the international level, which means that our diplomatic action must take into account this climate issue. In our relationship with other countries, in our relationship with other regions of the world, we have an obligation to place this issue at the center of our diplomatic concerns and, therefore, I would like to congratulate the authors of this report on the opportunity and the quality of it.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, the protection of the environment must obviously guide the European Union's foreign policy, and of course the protection of the environment must be a necessary condition for the conclusion of international conventions. But, Commissioner, we have to look at our house, see how we protect the environment ourselves, and we have to enforce environmental legislation. I had asked a relevant question about the case of Karystia, an area in Evia, Greece. Forty-two wind farms with a capacity of 700 megawatts are planned there, and according to a reply I received in November 2017 from Mr. Vella, European Union legislation on the design and installation of wind farms is being violated, and the Commission said it would refer Greece to the European Court of Justice. We expect actions to take place since then, because the multinationals continue to build the wind farms illegally and the Commission has yet to refer Greece to Court. We are waiting for this to happen.

name: Julia REID
text: – Madam President, the report states that we are facing an increased urgency for climate action and that there is a need for robust global implementation of the Paris Agreement. Yet there has been no discernible increase in global temperatures since the late 90s, despite an increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide. To date, the EU’s implementation of the Paris Agreement, in conjunction with its climate policies, has seen large—scale carbon leakage from the EU to third countries, whose energy dependent industries, such as those producing ammonia, leave, taking thousands of jobs with them. An unforeseen circumstance of driving ammonia production to countries outside the EU, such as China and India, which now account for 60% of production, has perversely led to a shortage of carbon dioxide in the EU, causing problems for bakeries, abattoirs, breweries, manufacturers of soft drinks and food packaging companies. In my opinion, the EU should adopt a wait—and—see attitude, rather than continue along the path of decarbonisation.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, first of all, compliments to Arne Lietz and Jo Leinen, my good friend, on their good work in the climate diplomacy proposals. Having represented the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) on the Paris Agreement, COP 21, and subsequently in Marrakech, COP 22, I think it was refreshing and uplifting for all of us that we did get a global agreement, hopefully to eliminate climate change and global warming.  Now we have to implement it and indeed I think we can be very pleased with the work we have done in the whole clean energy package. I was the rapporteur for Parliament on the renewable energy file. We have agreed on a 32% target and a 32.5% target for energy efficiency, and I think Europe can certainly say that it is putting its own house in order and giving leadership to the rest of the world, on which it is to be complimented. We have, of course, a duty to help the third countries in particular. I was pleased that Commissioner Arias Cañete, who has been so active in this area throughout his Commissionership, pointed out the role we are playing in terms of giving finance, but we also have to share perspectives and knowledge not just with third countries, but also the industrialised world, because this is a global problem.  Finally, I just want to say that Ms Boylan referred to Ireland and I would agree that, up until now, we haven’t been very good, but our Taoiseach, Leo Varadkar, was here in January. He said that we were laggards in the past, but we are not going to be in the future.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue—card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: blue-card question. – I would like to ask my fellow Irish MEP, Mr Kelly, if he shares the same vision of climate diplomacy as his party in the Irish Government, because it is a type of climate policy that actually goes into international negotiations and argues for loopholes to dilute the laws. It’s the type of climate diplomacy that Climate Action Network referred to as playing a negative role in the EU 2030 legislation. So is that the type of climate diplomacy that you and Leo Varadkar advocate?

name: Seán KELLY
text: blue-card answer. – That’s a very negative view of Ireland. As I said, we admit – and we weren’t in government, only for the last couple of years – that Ireland hasn’t played its part in reaching its 2020 targets, but that is going to change. Indeed, we are right now drawing up proposals to ensure that we will lead the way, especially in reaching our 2030 targets, and also play our role internationally, cooperating with the Commission in putting these climate diplomacy proposals into operation internationally. Ireland will not be found wanting, and I am very pleased to tell Ms Boylan that.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: - Madam President, do not count on me to support yet another strengthening of the Commission's prerogatives on this subject. Because if our planet is doing so badly, it is because of the intensification of flows, but also of the free trade treaties defended by the European Union or agricultural productivism, which is engraved in stone in the European treaties. Likewise, this text calls on the Union and its Member States to be active partners at the international level, but aspires for the European Union to speak with one voice. But what are states for? To do figuration? So, no, I do not want to give the Commission an active role for COP 24, nor to see it raise the level of ambition of the Paris Agreement. No, I am not committing the Union to play an international role in carbon markets. And finally, no, I do not want additional expenditure within the European External Action Service and the Commission.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner Cañete, the European Union is the most important international player in tackling climate change, and that is why climate diplomacy is the tool that must work dynamically and at the same time horizontally in all our political actions. The Union's climate diplomacy must be professional, financially strengthened, more coherent and coordinated, so that the dimension of tackling climate change is everywhere: security, migration, trade agreements, foreign investment, everywhere . One area in which climate change will be tested is the field of immigration, and that is where the Union's climate diplomacy must be present, not only to secure the citizens of the Union, but also to ensure that citizens are ready to emigrate. , because of the problems they will face from climate change. Finally, said the Commissioner, we are not going back to Paris. Climate diplomacy is necessary to reward or even point out negligence within the Union and we must start with ourselves.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the historical responsibility for climate change and the damage it causes lies solely with the largest emitters: Asia, North America and Europe are the most industrialized regions of the world and these are the areas that in fact also direct the development of the poorest countries. Trump's decision to remove the country that generates the most emissions in the world from international commitments must once again be stigmatized and we know that climate change, as well as the environment, also affects social injustice, migration, famine, disease and poverty. The leadership of the Union led to the signing of the Paris Agreement but the global transition to a zero-carbon economy and resilient to climate change requires huge investments, which even Europe does not always seem willing to grant. Instead, we must invest decisively and without hesitation in the sustainable economy, strengthening our environmental leadership and forcing other economies to do the same so as not to be left out.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I want to thank everyone for preparing this report and for the opportunity to engage in this important debate. Climate diplomacy encompasses many aspects which we have touched on in this discussion – implementation and ambition under the Paris Agreement, migration, climate security, climate finance and, last but not least, our domestic commitments and actions here in the European Union. There was a direct question from Mr Leinen related to the Paris Agreement and trade agreements, and I understand that discussions are ongoing in the Council and at DG level on the complex question of potentially including the Paris Agreement as an essential element in the political process of the European Union’s international agreements. The European Union has already committed to the promotion of the Paris Agreement in its bilateral relations, and in trade relations in particular we have included an obligation to implement effectively the Paris Agreement in our more recentagreements.  But elevating the importance of the Paris Agreement further, putting it on a par with human rights, would also send a strong signal that the European Union’s international agreements, including trade agreements, are tools to help save globalisation, not only in economic terms, but also through protecting and promoting European Union values. However, it is a step that should not be taken lightly. It needs to be done in a manner that is operational in practice, and the Paris Agreement is designed to be facilitative, non-intrusive, non-punitive and respectful of national sovereignty.  We need to keep this in mind, but the Commission is ready to act as a facilitator in the discussions and to provide any information that could usefully inform this analysis. I will conclude by saying that I count on the commitment of this Parliament and its support, and I look forward to further discussions as we prepare for COP 24.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! Thank you very much for the lengthy debate, and thank you also the Commissioner for his answer. Several things have been raised, some of which I would like to address. Droughts and storms were also addressed in particular. There was now a conference of the Commission on the subject of climate diplomacy, climate and security, and here I would like to cite an example where we as parliament have had contact, for example in states and with representatives of Iran who, for their part, have difficulties in international negotiations. But when it comes to the question of the climate, the question of environmental damage and the question of droughts, there have been major inquiries, and certainly in the direction of the European Union. This means that climate diplomacy is also an introductory topic for diplomatic talks, even with states that have difficulties here. I would also like to mention an example on issues of multilateralism. We have here - you said it, Commissioner - the USA and Canada as interlocutors. And here Europe shows leadership initiative, namely in the situation that we are not only doing diplomacy towards the White House, but also on campaigns "We are still in" or campaigns by the governors who are committed to the implementation of the Paris Climate Agreement, a best practice As the saying goes, the European Union, not just the European delegation, which deals with all levels, but also the European Parliament. We have an office of the European Parliament there, and this cooperation on climate protection is going very well here. On the question of mainstreaming around Katowice, I would definitely like to mention one point again. The European Union must present the strategy for the Sustainable Development Goals in New York in 2019. Here it really makes sense for us to show that the climate issue is of outstanding importance. I would like to close with the point that was mentioned, namely how we also achieve technologies - also an important point, a goal in the area of ​​the Sustainable Development Goals -, energy supply and decarbonization, especially in our European neighborhood. North Africa has been mentioned here. This is about using renewable energies, from large projects to private households. Thank you very much, and I am now looking forward to the joint implementation in the months and years to come, that we as the European Parliament are increasingly addressing this issue as a foreign policy issue.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President! I note that we have a great consensus here in the plenary that climate protection is a very important task, and a global task at that - many speakers here have confirmed that again. It is all the more sad that here in the European Parliament we have climate opponents and climate skeptics who still deny that there is climate protection. It is also significant that the colleagues, Ms. Reid and Ms. D'Ornano, read some statement from the paper for a minute and then immediately disappear from the plenary chamber. This is as dubious as it can be, that speaks for itself, that an important problem is not seriously considered here. I believe that we do indeed need to pay more attention to the issue of climate refugees. I know that we are still debating whether there should be legal status for people who have to leave their homeland. But we will see that hundreds of thousands, millions of people actually hike and go because they no longer have water, because they have nothing more to eat - this is a big issue that we cannot avoid. In this context, we need a lot more attention to our neighboring continent, Africa, and I can only repeat once again that our trade policy, our development policy must be geared to sustainable development in Africa and that we have to make up for something. Mr Arias Cañete, I think it is good news that we are filling our trade agreements with elements of the Paris Agreement, because it would somehow no longer be appropriate for us to pursue free trade and to leave aside the sustainable elements of the climate change agreement. That also creates unfair competition, that is the past, that is no longer the future. I'm looking forward to a good set-up tomorrow and to the work after that.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: Thank you very much, honorable Members, and thank you very much to the Commission for your contribution.I close the debate.The vote will take place tomorrow, Tuesday.Dear colleagues!Allow me to greet all of you and the Commissioner with respect and love tonight.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- Climate change is having an increasing and serious impact on various aspects of human life and the geopolitical situation.Given the EU's leading role in combating climate change and the goals stemming from the Paris Agreement, it is important that the EU has a clear understanding of how to better shape climate diplomacy in the international environment.This requires the development of an action plan, the improvement of EU structures in the EU institutions and the involvement of more Member States as well as other stakeholders such as the research community, the private sector, etc.It is also important to address the causal link between climate change and migration.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: written. Although some members of this and other forums deny it, the evidence of climate change is overwhelming, with anomalies increasingly frequent and damaging. 40% of the world's population lives in coastal areas, at risk of losing their homes and their way of life. Exceeding 1.5 ° C global temperature would lead to unprecedented changes. In extreme cases, some states will be engulfed by the sea or cyclones like the Marshall Islands. The fight against climate change is a global task. Human activity affects us equally and this fight must be egalitarian and in solidarity. For this reason, climate diplomacy must serve to put compliance with the climate agreement before any other trade agreement of the EU with third countries, especially so as not to give an advantage in commercial relations to those who are not signatories or noncompliants. In this sense, it is not necessary to go to the Pacific to apply climate diplomacy, as many Member States will not meet the emissions reduction and renewables targets in 2020, and our poorer neighbors in the Baltic, including within the Energy Union, they plan to burn lignite without any internalization of the CO2 emitted. Let's apply it here too.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: signed up. - It is well known that the effects of climate change are increasingly affecting various aspects of human life, as well as development opportunities, geopolitical order and global stability. This own-initiative report welcomes the importance of climate diplomacy for the EU, a form of foreign policy involving third-country governments and non-governmental actors globally, to promote the fight against climate change and carbon emissions. Given the EU's role as an international leader in climate change and its commitments to the implementation of sustainable development strategies and compliance with the Paris Agreement, the report calls for a coherent and coordinated approach to EU climate diplomacy, improvements in its structure, additional financial and human resources, and the integration of the climate diplomacy dimension into the EU's external relations. Also, given the importance of the impact of climate change on human life, peace and stability, we agree that action in the field of climate is a matter of improving security and living conditions worldwide and that the EU should be more proactive in the process of building alliances to implement the Paris Agreement.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. - The effects of climate change are having an increasingly serious impact on many aspects of the natural environment, and thus also human life. The European Union is one of the main players in climate action and plays a leading role in international negotiations on climate change. It uses "climate diplomacy" to forge strategic alliances to fight together against climate change. It is a key element of preventive and sustainable development in relation to climate threats. "Climate diplomacy" is a form of targeted foreign policy aimed at involving third country governments and non-governmental actors around the world to promote the fight against climate change. Its main strategic goals are the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and the fight against poorly developed environmental protection policy. It is particularly important to support developing countries in their search for a sustainable and environmentally friendly development path. In the February conclusions of the EU Foreign Affairs Council, climate security was identified as a very important topic and underlined that climate change had a significant impact on international stability and security. The Council calls for an effective response to climate security threats in different policy areas and underlines the importance of taking action as soon as it receives individual analyzes of climate threats.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the debate on the recommendation by Eugen Freund, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the 73rd session of the UN General Assembly (2018/2040 (INI)) (A8-0230 / 2018).

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, as every year, this report gives us an opportunity to present the views of the European Parliament both on our relations with the United Nations and on the most pressing issues that the UN is facing. The global strategy on the US foreign and security policy affirms that the EU will strive for a strong United Nations as a bedrock of the multilateral rules-based order. The UN brings unique value-added measures to our citizens. Nevertheless, let me start with a bleak observation. If Winston Churchill were alive, what would he have said about the UN? It might have sounded like this: ‘The United Nations is a weak organisation, but I don’t know a better one.’ In my opinion, which is reflected in the report, this weakness has a structural origin and it has a name: it is called the Security Council. It is, by the way, also the most powerful body within the United Nations. Let me illustrate this with an example. In April of this year, the Security Council held a debate about what turned out to be a chemical attack in Syria. The question we all had on our mind was: how will the United Nations react to this atrocity? But unfortunately, just as in so many other cases we have observed, the veto of one superpower blocked the resolution condemning the attack, and so each side voted against the other’s proposals. When the United States and Russia are at odds, nothing moves and people keep suffering or even dying. This is one of the calamitous consequences of the power of veto. Our report therefore urges all those responsible to redouble their efforts to change both the veto right and the composition of the Security Council. It was enshrined in the Charter of the United Nations, which was adopted a few months after the end of World War II. The world of today is significantly different from that of the past 70-odd years, but the UN Security Council has practically remained the same. We actively support the UN Secretary General in his reform agenda to streamline the peace and security structure, which needs to become more efficient, focused and operational. We also support the Secretary General’s efforts in making a substantial change in order to align the UN development system with the priorities of Agenda 2030 and the Sustainable Development Goals. We must not forget that the EU and its Member States were instrumental in shaping the global UN 2030 agenda, and the EU remains committed to being a front runner in mobilising all means of implementation and ensuring strong follow-up. We continue to support the Women, Peace and Security Agenda. The fact is that when women participate in peace processes, we have seen over and over again that peace agreements last significantly longer. Let me now turn to disturbing trends: sexual violence, including rape, is still being used as a weapon and constitutes a war crime. We therefore call for strengthened protection of women and girls in conflict areas. With regard to weapons of mass destruction and the issue of non-proliferation, we support all UN actions, as we do when we promote the full implementation of the Arms Trade Treaty (ATT) and encourage all UN Member States to sign and ratify it. As for human rights, we are very concerned to observe an ever-tighter space for civil society around the world, and we would emphasise that human rights are indivisible, interdependent and inter-related. When we speak of human rights, this is directly related to our support for the UN Global Compacts on Migration and on Refugees. We would strongly remind the international community to provide enough financial support for the UN High Commission on Refugees in order to be able fully to protect refugees around the world. I may pick up on a few outstanding issues in my final statement at the end of the debate and I hope that, despite some differences, you will support this important report.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, today’s discussion shows the strong synergies and common ground between the European Parliament report and the European Union priorities for the United Nations and the 73rd United Nations General Assembly, adopted at the Foreign Affairs Council on 25 June. In the coming year the European Union will focus on peace and conflict prevention, a common positive agenda with the promotion and protection of human rights at the heart of multilateralism, and on expanding global engagement on issues such as climate action, the environment, migration, counterterrorism and the non-proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. These are set priorities and I see in the draft European Parliament recommendation the same narrative and key priorities. In the year ahead of us we need to capitalise on this common agenda in our changing global landscape. The European Union will strive for a strong United Nations as the bedrock of the multilateral rules-based order. This will be a decisive year for UN reform, and the European Union is a strong supporter of the United Nations Secretary-General’s ambitious reform agenda. The European Union has a strategic interest in seeing reforms unfold this year and we will vigorously support their implementation. I also want to say that I am pleased to see UN reform as a point in Parliament’s report for the first time. Enhanced cooperation with the African Union (AU) is key. The ground-breaking joint trilateral AU-EU-United Nations work on Libyan migration, aims to pave the way for enhanced cooperation on the wider peace and security agenda. The support being provided to the G5 Sahel Joint Force is a key example of the importance of investing in global security partnerships, and we are happy to see Parliament’s report welcoming trilateral cooperation as a strong means of strengthening multilateralism. We see the 70th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights as an opportunity to advance this work at a time of negative threats. We both say that human rights are at the heart of multilateralism. Looking ahead, European Union unity is essential in order to fortify multilateralism and the current strong presence of European Union Member States at the UN Security Council contributes to positive forward momentum. A lot can be achieved through this European Union presence. Let me be more specific on our three interlinked priorities. On peace and conflict prevention the European Union will pursue an integrated approach, deploying all its tools and policies in support of prevention. Meaningful participation by women and youth in all aspects of peace and conflict prevention is critical to success, including in peace processes. Mediation is also a crucial tool to foster peace. In the coming year the European Union will further enhance cooperation with the UN on mediation and will step up efforts to carry out joint mediation actions, including with the AU and other partners. The European Union supports efforts to improve the performance of peace-keeping in order to protect populations better. In this respect, the European Union supports the UN action for peacekeeping initiatives. This will focus on prevention and calls for an integrated approach. Peace and security are indivisible from sustainable development and human rights. On our common positive agenda this year, marking the 70th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the European Union strongly supports the pledge by the UN Secretary-General to move forwards on the human rights agenda, particularly at a time when there have been serious negative trends around the world in human rights. The 2030 Agenda is our joint blueprint for action in the years ahead, across all the pillars of the United Nations. The European Union sees the Sustainable Development Goals as an extraordinary opportunity to eradicate poverty and achieve sustainable development in its three dimensions – economic, societal and environmental. The EU-UN Spotlight Initiative to eliminate violence against women and girls, launched in 2017, illustrates an innovative, joined-up approach. This initiative also reaffirms the European Union’s resolute and unwavering commitment to gender equality and women’s and girls’ empowerment – a common EU- UN imperative. Finally, on the issue of expanding our global engagement, the coming year will be crucial to accelerating climate action and operationalising the landmark Paris Agreement. Together with China and Canada, the European Union organised the 2018 Ministerial on Climate Action, renewing global momentum towards the effective implementation of the Paris Agreement. With regard to migration, the European Union and its Member States are proactively engaged in the United Nations processes shaping the .. migration response firmly on the UN Agenda. The European Union will continue to intensify its efforts to strengthen the respect for international humanitarian law, as well as refugee law and international human rights law. ... full, prompt, impartial and effective investigation in cases of violations. May I close by signalling once again my appreciation of Parliament’s role and my gratitude to the rapporteur, Mr Freund, and for his support in keeping these important issues high on the international agenda.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, as usual, we will make our contribution to defining a position of the European Union for the next session of the United Nations General Assembly. Traditionally, this exercise has been fairly consensual, because here we are all committed to defending multilateralism and building a global legal order that reflects the values ​​we defend in Europe. Cooperation with the United Nations is also of paramount importance to respond to the challenges we face, whether it be the multiplication of conflicts, terrorism, migration, climate change or the implementation of the 2030 Agenda. I am also satisfied that, thanks to my amendments, a chapter on development has been introduced into the text, mentioning in particular the coherence of policies in favor of development. I regret, however, that, this year, a certain number of questions which divide us are found in the text we are going to vote on, in particular paragraphs 1 (x) on Western Sahara and 1 (abm) on the recognition of a status protection for climate refugees. On both points, the EPP finds the formulations unacceptable and will not be able to support the text if they are maintained. It would be a real shame to come to this, since the messages conveyed in the other points of the recommendation would necessarily be weakened.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the 73rd session of the UN General Assembly opens under the banner of a changed world situation characterized by enormous uncertainty. The conflicts in several countries and the migratory phenomenon are causing enormous destabilization in almost the whole planet, putting a strain on established democratic structures, peace and human rights. For this reason, the task of nations should be to strengthen the role of the UN, and not to undermine it by returning to short-sighted national sovereignties or absurd vetoes. After all, we have already seen how many failures were produced when international economic institutions were mainly guided by commercial and financial selfishness and interests. Hence our criticism of the announced US withdrawal from the Human Rights Council, a wrong decision because it will be impossible to face global challenges by shirking a necessary and indispensable common and shared action, which only the UN can guarantee.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Freud, and all shadow rapporteurs for their significant efforts in the preparation of this recommendation. It is indeed more important for the European Union to point out a list of common priorities for the upcoming United Nations General Assembly, because the multilateral order is being challenged in a way that we haven’t seen in decades. As many Member States are divided on numerous global issues, I am convinced this recommendation will be a good opportunity to show the world community that the EU could speak in one single voice. We need to increase the influence of the EU and its Member States inside the United Nations system and to stand firm behind our values. I am very pleased that the recommendation clearly highlighted the EU as one of the most dedicated defenders and promoters of human rights, fundamental freedoms, cultural values, diversity, democracy and the rule of law. However, the European Union should continue to support multilateral attempts to find lasting political and peaceful solutions to ongoing conflicts in the Middle East and North Africa, as well as to continue to call for full respect for internationally recognised borders and the territorial integrity of Eastern European and South Caucasus countries, and to support and reinvigorate diplomatic efforts for a peaceful settlement of ongoing and protracted conflicts. Finally, it is important to point out our continued support for environmental sustainability, notably in the fight against climate change, by promoting international measures.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, Commissioner! With the resolution that we are voting on this week, the High Representative and her diplomats have received a strong recommendation for clear political action. It is precise with regard to the solutions that we urgently need in order to meet the common challenges in order to live in peace and mutual balance. Thank you, colleague, friend, for your work on this. We have an extensive chapter on the manifold questions of peace and disarmament and, above all, an explicit commitment to the Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons. I expect you to act decisively in support of this agreement from the European Union. Do not follow the argumentation attempts of the German Foreign Minister, who opposes the will of 122 states. Today all steps towards the abolition of nuclear weapons and their non-proliferation must be taken. The European Parliament gives you strong backing with regard to a legally binding international instrument that regulates the compliance with human rights norms by commercial enterprises. The positions on the Paris Agreement on Climate Change and the implementation of the UN Sustainable Development Goals of the 2030 Agenda are also strong and clear, and this, colleague Dan Preda, certainly includes the obligations for people who are particularly affected by climate change. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr Scholz, you were right to say that the UN is paralyzed today.The Security Council is stalling, the General Assembly is not particularly dynamic, and unfortunately we are in a sad state.Would you agree that we need a new element in the UN, that the parliaments are more strongly represented there, maybe one day even with a parliamentary assembly?We are an open stage, we have really dynamic discussions and we could bring life to the UN.It would be a shame if this organization stagnated.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr Leinen, I agree with you.We also need a stronger democratization of the United Nations, a tie back to what ministers, diplomats and ambassadors of the various states are doing there.In this respect, a parliamentary expansion of this UN, this unique world assembly, would certainly be urgently needed.And that could also stimulate the parliamentarians to assume more responsibility for the work of this UN, here in the European Parliament as well as at the level of the national parliaments.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! This report contains a clear message, a clear commitment to multilateralism as the central guarantor of peace and human rights in the world. Given the global challenges, this commitment is more relevant than ever. These challenges include armed conflicts in Europe's neighborhood with no prospects for a solution, a lack of prosecution for those responsible for war crimes and human rights violations, global migratory movements of which only a fraction reaches Europe, and the international failure to effectively limit global warming. This report contains concrete reform proposals to enable the United Nations to act more effectively. We also call for the role of the International Criminal Court to be strengthened so that those responsible for the most serious international crimes are brought to justice. In this context, in the last urgency resolution of the European Parliament on Myanmar, we proposed that the General Assembly launch an independent and international investigation into human rights violations against the Rohingya. The present report takes a clear position against the dangerous US foreign policy. It is demanded that the nuclear deal with Iran be adhered to. The USA's decision to withdraw from the UN Human Rights Council is also regretted, and finally it is warned that the USA must also be committed to climate protection through international agreements. Given the importance of this report for multilateralism, I find it very unfortunate that the Conservative groups refused to accept this report when they voted in the Committee on Foreign Affairs and abstained or voted against it. I hope you will correct that in plenary.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: - Madam President, I thank the rapporteur, Mr Freund, for his efforts for his report. I hope I can vote in favor of it if the difficulties that the text currently poses for my group are resolved. The European Union needs to collaborate with the United Nations and wants to be a global player, because the United Nations occupies a key place in world governance. Many of today's challenges are global; regional solutions are insufficient. I am thinking of climate change, of terrorism, of the management of migratory flows ... The latter is a serious challenge to which the European Union has not yet found adequate solutions. It is essential, first of all, to cooperate with the countries of the southern Mediterranean and with the African countries and, also, to actively contribute to economic and social change in Africa, whose population continues to increase. Otherwise, the problem, in the medium term, will be insoluble. For the rest, I hope that the December meeting in Marrakech will be an incentive to successfully conclude the global compact that is being negotiated within the framework of the United Nations. Peace and security are also an essential objective of the United Nations. We are very close to the conflicts in Libya and Syria and also the serious problems of the Sahel. As we have sadly lived through these days, Europe cannot escape its geography. Again, cooperation with the United Nations and with regional bodies, especially the African Union, is essential. Finished. This year marks - as has been said - the 70th anniversary of the Declaration of Human Rights, which has given the United Nations an important ethical dimension. Many efforts are still needed for us to achieve universal respect for fundamental freedoms, one of the hallmarks of the European Union.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I greatly appreciate the proposals that are central in Mr Freund’s report and I want to congratulate him on this really good job. I am happy to see that one of the priorities of the 73rd United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) will be strengthening multilateralism. This is also the main goal of the European Union. However, it is important that we have realistic expectations of this meeting. I believe that the EU needs to promote a rule-based order and binding commitments of the UNGA. Only in such a way can we hope for improvements. Just take the example of the deeply disappointing results of the European Council last week. If we do not adopt binding measures, it means that our desire to reform the system is not sincere. I hope that in September the EU will be convincing in pushing forward the reform of the UN Security Council because the EU needs a permanent seat there as one of the most foreign policy actors.

name: Elmar BROK
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Let me make two comments. First: I think this is the opportunity, in view of the international situation and American behavior, to make a point for the multilateral rule-based organization, this crucial foundation for security, for economic development. This must not be destroyed in disarray. Let me make a second comment: the European Council has dealt intensively with the issue of migration. If, in view of the 65 million refugees on this earth, we want to get things under control and stop migratory movements, it will only work - also with European support - if the United Nations also takes over the protection of these refugees in the camps, for example in Libya not so that the gangs run the camps there, rape and enslave the people, but that these camps are appropriately secured at the level of the United Nations so that the people can be returned. I believe that for this reason the European Union has good reason to work closely with the United Nations and to implement these decisions made last week.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: - Madam President, Commissioner Cañete, in the context of this resolution and in the current political context of the European Union facing an unresolved migration issue, I would like to emphasize the need for effective coordination on the negotiation of two global agreements on refugees and migration, in order to prepare a more effective international response. to this problem. All countries facing a wave of refugees must have adequate support provided and need to be helped to find a solution based on respect for human rights. Facing the problem of transnational organized crime, which uses the emergence of migration waves as a new source of enrichment, will protect global peace and security as well as the stability of the European Union's borders. I would like to emphasize in the end that the European Union, which provides 75 billion euros in development aid, is positioned as the world's leading donor. However, what is needed is higher development aid expenditures by other United Nations member states, as well as their more responsible approach in implementing and respecting fundamental human rights. All this is necessary in order for us to have a new and reformed United Nations, whose foundation and greatest supporter is the European Union.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: - (FI) Mr President, I personally hope that the European Union could make the strengthening of the United Nations the number one priority in its foreign and security policy.We will need more and more a multilateral basis for cooperation that is legitimate, just as only the United Nations can have.This system may never, but especially recently, have had too many advocates.I think that our role, at least as strongly as in climate policy, would be to put the strengthening of the UN at the center.It also means taking practical measures, for example in the Millennium Development Goals' own assessment, to assess the creation of its own performance indicators, and also to raise it in cooperation with third countries as part of, for example, climate policy.Hopefully, when we just talked about climate, the EU could also incorporate the climate refugee debate and its content into its UN policy in the future.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: - Madam President, a very interesting report and I think that promoting peace, security and conflict prevention has been and remains a long-standing European Union priority at the UN. Added to this is our concern for the international scourge, the modern scourge of terrorism. However, Commissioner, coming from a small European Union Member State that remains a victim of invasion and occupation by Turkey, I have a personal perception of the violence stemming from the force of arms. I am the same refugee from the occupied part of Cyprus. Nevertheless, in the Eastern Mediterranean, with the help of the European Union, we are trying to build a basin of cooperation between the states of the region. The UN Convention on the Law of the Sea is what governs our cooperation. And I close with one last word: I also emphasize the role of the International Criminal Court, so that the impunity of criminals stops and also works preventively.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, the 73rd session of the UN General Assembly is very important. We have heard from all sides that we need to address the issues of terrorism, environmental protection, immigration, security, but I see that we are forgetting here in the European Union that there is a country, Cyprus, in which Turkey has invaded. since 1974 and illegally occupies 37% of the territory of the Republic of Cyprus and has troops there. I believe that this issue should be the subject of every session of the UN General Assembly, because that way the message can be passed that the occupation troops will leave Cyprus one day, to force Turkey to act in accordance with international law. to stop threatening Greece, to stop threatening Cyprus. It must be a matter of top priority at the 73rd session of the UN General Assembly.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like thank all the honourable Members who have participated in this very interesting debate for their contributions.  In these turbulent times the European Union and the United Nations are indispensable partners. The European Union-United Nation partnership is both stronger and more important than ever, because today is the time to both defend our multilateral achievements, as well as to to build bridges with others to promote the multilateral rules-based order. Together, the European Union and the United Nations will continue to engage as a positive force for change. A new overarching European Union-UN strategic partnership to step up cooperation and catalyse new action is needed for the future.  On the issue of migration, which has been raised by some honourable Members, over the past years the European Union has built a comprehensive approach to addressing migration and forced displacement. The European Union will continue its strong engagement in both processes, shaping the content and placing migration and refugee response firmly on the United Nations agenda. The European Union will proactively engage to achieve robust, balanced and inclusive global compacts, and we are keen to work hand in hand with all partners towards a successful outcome. I would like to close by reiterating my gratitude to the rapporteur Mr Freund for his excellent report.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to start by thanking Mr Arias Cañete, on behalf of the Commission, for his unwavering support for this report. In am really grateful for it.  This stands in stark contrast to the speech that Mr Preda gave here. I am deeply disappointed that Mr Preda left the room immediately after his speech and I also deeply regret that, due to some – as a matter of fact, two – divisive issues, Mr Preda indicated that he would not support the report. That will mean that he – and how many others we don’t know – will not support the UN in its efforts to provide peace. They will not support the fight against sexual violence against women and girls, they will not support standing up for human rights, they will not support the global compact on migration and refugees, and they will not support the necessary reform initiatives of the UN Secretary—General, to name just a few of the important issues.  I would also like to mention at the end that we have to insist that, due to the ever-growing number of tasks for the UN system, we demand adequate financing by its member states. We deplore that there is a growing gap between the organisation’s needs and the funding provided for it. Last, but certainly not least, we reaffirm our unwavering commitment to the Paris Climate Accord and stress the need for its implementation globally. We must not forget that the effect of climate change will – or already does – lead to severe changes in the lifestyle of the population around the world. Colleagues – whoever is left here – let me express my sincere hope that this report, even when we do not agree on everything, still will find the broadest majority possible. Let me add that I think that it will be an embarrassment if one of the largest parties here in the House will not support this report. At the very end, I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs, and particularly the Secretariat of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, without which this report would not have seen the light of day.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on the role of cities in the EU institutional framework (2017/2037 (INI)) (A8-0203 / 2018).

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: rapporteur. - Madam President! I am honored to present, on behalf of myself and of the AFCO Committee, a report on the position of cities in the functioning of the European Union. I would like to extend my sincere thanks to everyone who worked on this report. First of all, the shadow rapporteurs for their inventiveness, ideas and proposals, which were mostly included in the recommendation presented at the plenary session of the European Parliament. I would like to thank very much Mr Olbrycht, representing the REGI committee, who contributed autonomously to this report. The report responds to a new phenomenon, and good policy should respond to new phenomena. This new phenomenon is the accumulation in cities of a number of very important problems affecting the areas of EU policy. These are issues of our safety, the quality of public services, environmental protection, and in many cities also immigration and social exclusion. Hence the belief that the position of cities and their role in the functioning of the European Union should be greater than before. The report is based on the conviction that cities, where European problems are increasingly concentrated, play too little role in designing, implementing and debating the shape of EU policies. The report presents innovations within the framework of the treaty regulations: a stronger position of cities in the Committee of the Regions, increasing the role of city associations - Eurocities and the Council of European Municipalities and Regions - in the process of consulting and agreeing decisions, and finally strengthening the platforms established at the initiative of the European Commission. The report also recommends that the European Council should establish closer contact with local authorities. What is characteristic of the report is a dynamic, full-fledged understanding of the city. The city is not only a political unit, an administrative structure under political control. A European city is more than that. It is a social node, it is a place where the media and non-governmental organizations operate. Virtually no continent in the world has a network of cities of this value.
