Hence the report's proposal that, at the initiative of the European Parliament and the Committee of the Regions, open forums for European debate should be created around city councils willing to undertake this work, which would be a place for discussing and designing EU policies. And finally, two reservations. This is not an idea of ​​fortifying cities against anyone else. This is an idea for multi-level management and synergy between the activity of states, cities, local and regional structures and the European Union itself. It is also not an idea of ​​the selfishness of big cities. The report covers cities and urban areas, including those outside metropolises. They, too, can bear the burden and responsibility for the development of Europe to a greater extent than before. That's it for explaining the core ideas and content of this report. I am sure that, as in the AFCO committee, it will be approved by the majority of political forces in the European Parliament.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: - Mr President, 70% of Europeans live in cities.The majority of our income comes from cities.Clearly, the vast majority of innovations arise in cities because the diversity of cities and the diversity of people are a favorable basis for the emergence of innovations with education.Cities also have a long way to go in terms of land use planning, increasing green spaces and tackling climate change, as has been seen in various projects across Europe.That is why I hope that the next Commission will be able to include clearly in its work program the strengthening of urban policy and, in that connection, the increase in land-use planning, even though there is no direct competence.In the report, I particularly appreciate the idea of replacing the new bodies with the Urban Policy Unit and its operationalization through the Committee of the Regions.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Madam President, before coming to this Parliament I was the Deputy Mayor of Leicester for six years. This is the tenth largest city in the UK, so I need no convincing of the important role – and indeed the huge potential – of cities in relation to the advancement of public policy and innovation of social progress. However, any new measures to strengthen the voice and the role of cities at European level must apply equally to all cities, regardless of size or perceived status. Furthermore, while cities have a hugely important role to play, we shouldn’t overlook the role, the potential and the contribution that towns and small urban areas, and indeed our rural communities, can make to those agendas as well.  There is a huge and growing risk and vulnerability in our politics that we become too focused on cities at the cost of the contribution that towns and rural areas can make. We need to be aware of that in considering the ideas before us in this report.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, the basic principle of the European Union is the principle of subsidiarity, which means that all decisions must be taken more closely by the citizens themselves. This means that a system of multi-level governance is taking shape in the European Union, so cities can and must now play a serious role in environmental protection, at the level of social policy, at the level of tackling poverty, through the implementation of programs. In this sense, therefore, the role of cities is serious and I would like to congratulate the fellow rapporteur on what he says in his report. The same, of course, applies to the role of the regions. But we must be careful: that the main pillar of the functioning of the European Union is the Member States and, therefore, the functioning of regions and cities must be complementary and support the pillar, that is, the Member States and not dissolve them. .

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, cities have always had a very special place in European history, because they have held special rights and led to the development of trade and education.Our democracy was born in the Greek polis.Even now, cities are primarily the focus of population development.We know that 70% of the European Union's population lives there today, and this trend continues to grow.I myself am more of a supporter of urbanization not spreading so fast and the countryside not to become depopulated.But the reality is simply relentless.The enlargement of cities and their agglomerations places new demands on them, as well as on their infrastructure, spatial planning, and it is therefore good that we are also considering, at European Union level, the role that cities play in the institutional framework.I support greater involvement of city representatives in consultations on measures and legislation, both in the form of the Committee of the Regions and in informal opportunities.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the importance of cities and their recognition as key players in effectively implementing European Union policies is a challenge at EU level. As you know, all cities are a place where many of Europe’s challenges, such as dealing with high unemployment, promoting social integration, fighting against climate change, and reducing air pollution or congestion, are specifically acute and must be dealt with. Cities are at the same time places of great opportunities to boost growth, create jobs and enhance productivity for the benefit of all European Union citizens. Local authorities are often the closest contact point for citizens as 70% of our population live in urban areas, as Ms Šojdrová has just stressed, and even more will live there in the future. Therefore, working with them for cities can only bring the European Union closer to its citizens. Therefore, the Commission welcomes Parliament’s resolution as cities’ challenges and opportunities are part of most of the European Union’s actions.  Without forgetting the role of the Committee of the Regions, the Commission recognises the need to strengthen the role of cities in shaping future European Union policies. The European Union’s regional and urban policy aims to improve territorial cohesion and support urban development in the European Union. The Commission often expresses the need for more systematic and structured dialogues with representatives of local and regional governments at an earlier stage in policymaking, but also to develop some multilateral governance mechanisms for better policymaking and implementation. In this respect, the Urban Agenda for the European Union is an important milestone towards reinforcement of the urban dimension in all the European Union’s relevant policies. Two years after the Pact of Amsterdam setting up the Urban Agenda for the European Union, much has already been achieved. A more coherent and coordinated approach on urban issues within the Commission is taking place. The implementation of the Urban Agenda for the European Union is ongoing, with 12 thematic partnerships successfully established, mobilising more than 84 cities, while key new partnerships on security in public spaces and on culture and cultural heritage are to come and three action plans have already been finalised.  A one-stop shop for cities pulls together all European Union information for cities and URBIS has been set up under the European Investment Advisory Hub to support the preparation of urban investment projects. In addition, globally the Urban Agenda for the European Union is meant to become the European Union contribution to the United Nations’ New Urban Agenda, the Habitat III Conference, and the Sustainable Development Goals.  The recent Commission proposal for the next multiannual financial framework and post—2020 funds regulation confronts this by dedicating one of the policy objectives for investments specifically to be close to citizens. And cities will benefit from a specific earmarking of 6% of the European Regional Development Fund and will be empowered to select projects and manage the funds themselves. Within the Common Provisions on the European Regional Development Fund Regulation, the Commission also proposes to create a unique European Urban Initiative. This initiative will provide a coherent offer of services for cities in terms of capacity-building, innovation and knowledge. It will also enable cities to play a further role in the European Union policymaking process by supporting the Urban Agenda for the European Union.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place tomorrow, Tuesday.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Joëlle Bergeron, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on three-dimensional printing: intellectual property rights and civil liability (2017/2007 (INI)) (A8-0223 / 2018).

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in my report on 3D printing, I have taken up most of the concerns that have been raised by my colleagues during our various meetings in the Committee on Legal Affairs. 3D printing raises specific questions, of a legal, ethical, health or safety nature. The issues are diverse and complex, but I have chosen to focus my report around two main areas: that of intellectual property law and issues related to civil liability, particularly in the event of the production of defective objects. Regarding civil liability in the event of defective or even dangerous products, the multiplicity of players involved in the production chain could indeed lead us to consider new provisions in order to best cover and compensate consumers in the event of damage. Safety issues are also paramount, and in particular when it comes to the production of spare parts that will affect the automotive, household appliances, aircraft parts and even firearms sectors. In this report, we have also addressed issues relating to the medical field or to the production of prostheses or organ reproduction. This poses real ethical questions, such as that of equal access to health care, and this constitutes health issues. I will also say a word about the economic and environmental benefits that 3D printing could bring in the future. I am thinking in particular of the production and storage costs which will in fact decrease. The second text on which this report is based concerns intellectual property law which can be undermined by 3D printing if this process is not properly framed. 3D printing may indeed facilitate acts of counterfeiting, not only by individuals who may benefit from the private copying exception, but also by organized networks making profits from the sale of counterfeit products. To this end, it seems to me essential to prevent counterfeiting that a legal 3D printing offer develops so that the private individual who wishes to print a work can do so without breaking the law and ensuring fair remuneration. of the author. Finally and briefly, there is one subject that particularly interested me, and this because of my former profession as an auctioneer, it is that of the revolution that is looming in graphic arts. Tomorrow, everyone will have reproduction software or 3D printers that will allow them to reproduce the greatest masterpieces of painting and sculpture in a perfect way. Achieving perfection in reproduction is just a matter of time. So, unless you have a gendarme behind each work, the question that arises is obviously that of the production of works of art, that of copyright and that of Copyright. So I ask these questions: Tomorrow, what will an original work mean if the copy is perfectly identical to the original? Why will the original be worth more than the copy? How to protect yourself against fakes? As you can see, my dear colleagues, it is essential to be able to answer these questions by allowing more traceability in works produced in three dimensions. However, it is not a question of slowing down innovation through law, by legislating more and more and by accumulating legal texts, but here to anticipate and see to what extent the existing rules will have to adapt or be completed. To conclude, we have worked on this report in a true spirit of collaboration with my colleagues from the different political groups in the Legal Affairs Committee. I would also like to point out that it was passed unanimously. I was very happy about it. This report respects our desire to supervise, without however legally restricting, this rapidly evolving technology, which will be beneficial in the medium or long term for our society and for the economy.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, 3D printing has great potential for achieving a wide range of socially beneficial goals. Above all, it makes it possible to concentrate production, which shortens the production process and reduces transport and storage costs. All this is, of course, ecological. For many decades, this method has been reserved for certain industries. In recent years, however, it has become increasingly accessible to other sectors and consumers. In the event of damage to a particular item, for example, it allows the consumer to make a spare part instead of purchasing a new product. This is, of course, also useful in terms of environmental protection, but it has its risks, and the rapporteur has mentioned some of them. As a member of the Committee on Culture and Education, I consider the risk of violating the rights of creators to be problematic. As market developments and demand suggest that 3D printing will become even more accessible and the risk of misuse will continue to increase, I welcome the suggestion that the Commission consider adopting specific regulation on certain aspects of this technology.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, the issue we are discussing about 3D printing is very important. I would like to insist on intellectual property rights, because copyright must be protected. If there is no copyright protection, there will be no creation and that must be the basis. Without this protection, I think we will have a lot of problems in the future. The second issue raised by the presentation, quite rightly, is civil liability, because there must be civil liability. There must be ways of compensating the consumers themselves in order for the internal market itself to work. And that means strict legislation, it means multiple rights of the consumer himself. Therefore, in relation to the issues raised by the report, which are too many, I would like to insist once again on intellectual property rights.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: - Madam President, this report clearly demonstrates the challenges and potential of three-dimensional printing, especially for our industries, and the possibilities for relocating activities.The issues related to intellectual property and civil liability are also precisely identified.We will have to remain particularly attentive to the development of this technology with regard to security (manufacture of weapons and explosives).We must also be vigilant with regard to the use of 3D printing in the medical field, in particular from an ethical point of view and equality in access to care.Finally, and I echo the recommendation of the rapporteur and colleague, Joëlle Bergeron, we must support this innovation with the law, without, however, the law becoming a brake or an excessive constraint on this promising technology.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank Ms Bergeron for her work on the challenges raised by the advent of three-dimensional printing in the field of intellectual property rights and civil liability. Parliament’s report comes at an important time as this enabling technology has the potential to boost innovation in our industry and to have an impact on our everyday life. The Commission is looking closely into this technology. We originally adopted a third Data Package and a communication on artificial intelligence in which we set out a comprehensive approach to artificial intelligence. Liability and intellectual property are part of this discussion. Honourable Members, as pointed out in Ms Bergeron’s report, the opportunities that 3D printing offers have increased in various areas of our economy, for both business and consumers. By allowing the timely manufacturing of customised objects, not intended for mass production, 3D printing has the potential to make production more flexible and to boost industrial development, in particular for small and medium-sized enterprises. To tap this potential we need a coherent legal framework that provides legal certainty for both consumers and businesses in the European Union. What do we currently have? The final result of the 3D printing process is a product, and in the European Union we have strict rules to ensure that products placed on the market are safe. We ensure safety whilst encouraging innovation through technology-neutral product rules – a major advantage in world trade. However, not all products are always safe and some can cause damage. That is why we have the Product Liability Directive in place. It ensures that producers and company suppliers are jointly and severally liable if products are defective. The directive covers all products from raw materials to highly complex and automated machinery, including the output of 3D printing. We originally evaluated the directive and did not come across any specific problems related to 3D printing, even though some questions remain regarding emerging digital technologies. Products today can be altered and changed after they are placed on the market. The production process may involve more and different actors than was the case in 1985 when the directive was adopted. In addition, there is no straightforward distinction between traditional products and new products. We should bear this in mind when looking at damage caused by products. We need simple liability rules that allow consumers to claim compensation for damage caused by defective products. To define how best to address this question, the Commission set up an expert group to discuss liability in relation to new technologies. We will issue guidance on the Product Liability Directive in mid-2019. At the same time, we will issue a report on the broader implications for, and potential gaps in, the liability and safety frameworks in respect of artificial intelligence, the internet of things, and robotics. We see intellectual property as a key element of our industrial policy strategy. Efficient, well-designed, and balanced intellectual property systems are key in promoting investment, innovation and growth. In the European Union we have top-quality common rules on IT protection, including unitary titles for trademarks and designs, which also allow citizens to defend these rights in practice. We have just lately successfully completed trademark reform at Union level. On 29 November 2017, we adopted the IP Package for a balanced IP system responding to today’s societal challenges. We have provided guidance on implementing the directive on the performance of intellectual property rights. We have also announced our actions to step up the fight against counterfeiting and piracy, and we are now in the process of reviewing some of the copyright rules in order to make our digital single market a reality. We expect that our copyright package will contribute to increasing the competitiveness of the European Union’s cultural and creative industries in the digital environment. It will also deliver more in terms of access to content by users and opportunities for creators, and will enhance the potential for all online operators. The question we need to ask ourselves is whether the robust framework I have just described is fit for purpose. The issue is actually a cross-cutting one with impacts not only on copyright protection but also on design rules, trademark and patent laws, as well as trade secrets. It is really the whole intellectual property spectrum which needs to be addressed. As for industrial applications which would not stifle innovation, aerospace is one such sector which sees a promising future in the application of 3D printing technology that will benefit our society. We need to anticipate new business models and assess the impacts of any changes in the IP framework. In conclusion, emerging digital technologies provide us with opportunities to see whether what we are doing is still fit for purpose. The European Union needs a liability and intellectual property rights framework that encourages innovation but also protects and fosters the uptake of emerging digital technologies. Rules on liability and intellectual property rights play an important role in creating this environment. Importantly, the European Parliament has identified similar issues related to technological progress. I look forward to working with you on finding the best way forward.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place tomorrow, Tuesday.And now I hand it over to my colleague representing the place, my colleague, Vice-President, and I apologize for leading the meeting with such a voice, I was at a great music festival in Sopron, where I was born, this weekend, and that is my voice.In any case, thank you for your patience and I wish you a very good job.Good night!Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: in writing. - The dynamic development of three-dimensional printing made it possible to produce more and more technologically advanced objects with the use of 3D printers. There are high expectations for the medical sector, where this type of technology could be used to manufacture dentures, dental implants and even organs. The same is happening in the aviation sector, where building lighter components will reduce costs by using less fuel. The growing availability of 3D printers also makes it possible to make prints at home, which brings with it challenges in terms of intellectual property law. Mapping a three-dimensional object in the digital world can be considered an adaptation or some other type of development because a computer graphic artist transfers a three-dimensional object to another artistic technique - a CAD file. In this context, without a doubt, the graphic designer should have the consent of the creator of the original that he reproduces. His work related to the creation of the CAD file will also be copyrighted. The author will also be an operator who uses a 3D printer to create a completely new piece. This is especially true for pen-type 3D printers that act like a brush, allowing anyone to create their own little works of art. In conclusion, in order to avoid infringement of intellectual property, the European Union should introduce new legal standards or adapt existing regulations to the new 3D technology.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is one-minute speeches (Rule 163).

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: - Small farmers are the backbone of European agriculture, accounting for two thirds of all farms in the European Union. These are often family farms that play an irreplaceable role in the life of their region. They provide local employment, maintain traditions and bring food to citizens grown without excessive chemical treatment. Unfortunately, they are often exposed to disproportionate pressure from competing large agribusinesses, and the situation in Slovakia is critical in this area, as some small farmers are driven from their land and prevented from working on it. It is unbelievable that this is happening with the blessing of the Slovak authorities, as evidenced in May at the European Parliament by the small farmers themselves, who do not know how to get justice. The murdered journalist Ján Kuciak also wrote about these cases. It is our duty to help small farmers: not only by putting pressure to investigate scandals and punishing the perpetrators, but especially by creating the conditions for receiving European aid fairly, thoroughly controlled and so that farmers can devote themselves to honest work instead of unnecessary paperwork.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: - Mr President, this is the map of the trans-European transport priority network proposed by the Commission (she showed a map). Totally unbalanced between the Atlantic corridor and the Mediterranean corridor. More than 1,300 kilometers have been incorporated into the Atlantic corridor in Spain. Zero, to the Mediterranean corridor. Neither the Commission nor the previous Government of Spain, of the Popular Party, have prioritized the Mediterranean rail networks, isolating the port of Valencia, which is the main port of Spain, concentrates more than 40% of the traffic and is the first container port from the Mediterranean. For this reason, I demand that the Commission, first, explain the reasons and technical criteria used to not incorporate the Madrid-Valencia axis in the Atlantic-Mediterranean corridor that connects Lisbon with Madrid and Valencia, nor the Zaragoza-Sagunto axis in the Cantabrian corridor -Mediterranean, which would allow the exit through the Cantabrian of all the products that daily enter the port of Valencia from the rest of Europe. And secondly, I ask the Commission to accept the amendments that I am going to table in this Parliament to correct this situation.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! At the last European Council summit on migration, the compromise was officially announced, but a few days after it it turns out that the summit's arrangements for accepting refugees are highly questionable. Apparently, it has been agreed to place the refugee centers outside the European Union, but other countries reject this idea. After the summit, Chancellor Merkel announced that fourteen European Union countries agreed to relocate refugees to their territories - three of the countries she mentioned have already denied this. The head of the European Council, Donald Tusk, is expected to speak tomorrow, but he may have been absent from the bilateral talks between the German Chancellor Angela Merkel and the heads of governments of these countries. As Members of the European Parliament, we have the right to explain what the outcome of the summit really was - whether an agreement was actually reached, or whether European public opinion is being defrauded to save the government coalition in Germany.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Mr President, our Union is made up of an amalgam of national entities and languages ​​that portrays our cultural and socio-political wealth. From that reality, building an identity, a European citizenship, is only possible by recognizing the other, assuming that they are not unequal: they are only different. That is why our diversity is a value and, therefore, imposing a ceiling of 3% to be able to participate in the distribution of seats resulting from the European elections breaks these principles. Many European political forces - such as my party, the Basque Nationalist Party -, which represent European national minorities, who govern in very significant territories of the Union, do not reach this percentage of the vote at the state level. Trying to exclude these realities —institutional and political— denies diversity, weakens democracy, alienates Europe from the people and will not help to solve territorial problems —which are a European issue, as Catalonia is— because the States, incapable of integrating their own diversity, unravel the European project. The electoral reform that seeks to impose this exclusion, disunites and denies this diversity.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: - Mr President, today Oriol Junqueras, former member of Parliament, and Joaquim Forn, Minister of the Interior of the Government of Catalonia, have served eight months in jail, two hundred and forty-two days unfairly deprived of liberty.They are two of the nine Catalan political prisoners who have been kidnapped for months and are away from their home and their families.Today we have also learned that the transfer of these prisoners to prisons in Catalonia is imminent.Transfer is a right.What would be fair is that our political prisoners were free, were with their families, in their homes.And what would also be fair is that one day those who have abused the figure of preventive detention and those who have twisted the law would have to give explanations for what they are doing.The prisoners will not be a bargaining chip, because their freedom remains to be resolved and the effective right to self-determination of our country remains to be resolved.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: - Mr President, first of all I want to express once again the support of our group for the fair strike of interpreters. Ladies and gentlemen, the Middle East and Eastern Mediterranean region is an active volcano. We have constant intense war conflicts. In other words, there is a need for peace to prevail and for problems to be resolved that have plagued the region for decades. One such problem is the Cyprus problem, the solution of which is more relevant today than ever and will offer a positive sign to the Union. It is one year since the Crans-Montana shipwreck. The stagnation in the negotiations was accompanied by Turkey's illegal activity within the Cypriot EEZ. No one can predict developments unless negotiations resume immediately with a view to reaching an agreement on the basis of the agreed solution framework as soon as possible. The forthcoming contacts of the Special Representative of the UN Secretary-General are an excellent opportunity to resume a meaningful dialogue on the Cyprus issue and direct talks. And the Secretary-General describes in his recent reports that they should start where they left off. The European Union as a whole must be activated, support the UN efforts, impose pressure and sanctions on Turkey, so that it can finally assume its responsibilities.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in these days Vercelli is experiencing yet another case of predatory globalization, allowed by the rules of the internal market and supported by a Europe that only knows how to turn its head to the other side. The Swedish multinational Perstorp had acquired the Italian Polioli a year ago, promising to keep production and jobs: but now it has announced the irrevocable closure of Polioli on 31 July next. It is clear that Perstorp's interest has never been to maintain production in Italy but to acquire know-how and above all Polioli's customer portfolio, to then close and abandon the seventy-two employees to their fate, insulting them with the mockery of a ridiculous good output of only one thousand euros. There may be nothing illegal about this but there should be, because the behavior of the Swedes is morally deplorable. Europe must legislate on corporate social responsibility as soon as possible and prevent such a predatory attitude.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: - Mr Chairman! We are voting this week to extend the life of a monster that shouldn't be born, and the sooner it dies the better. We shouldn't let him run away and lay eggs. I am talking about the directive on copyright in the digital single market. We have all been inundated with an avalanche of letters from voters who do not wish lawmakers to rummage through the internet. And there is no doubt in your opinion that voters do not want it. You cannot be a democrat at the same time and openly oppose and deceive a sovereign: extort his support, let alone such plans, and now pass laws on his behalf that he definitely does not want. You are acting against voters in the interests of a narrow lobby that is already wealthy and, in the name of greed, invented the concept of intellectual property. Intellectual property is no property, just as social justice is not justice, and the guinea pig is not a pig.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, I would like to express my concern about a new form of organized crime that threatens security and complicates the resolution of the migration crisis. This is a trade in stolen identity documents that help illegal migrants enter the European Union. Thanks to the right passports obtained, these people very easily avoid border controls, migration regulations and visa requirements. According to Europol, more than 200,000 people crossed European borders in this way last year. Security experts warn that these practices are the cause of the uncontrolled intrusion of criminals and terrorists into the European Union. Migrant smugglers are becoming more and more organized. They create sophisticated solutions and professional networks and also operate transnationally, making the security threat increasingly strong for the European Union. That is why I call on the European Commission to start addressing this issue and to come up with an effective solution.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, in the EU we continue to witness organised discrimination against many ethnic minorities. It is my duty to speak to you again about the shameful practice of discrimination against ethnic minorities in Latvia. All the rules we make in this House affect these people directly, although they are never consulted. Even in European elections they cannot vote and cannot hope for any political representation. The so—called ‘aliens’ amount to 12% of the population of Latvia, my country, and these 12% are excluded from any consultation. Until now, this anti—democratic practice has never been seriously discussed at governmental level in Latvia so my only hope is that it can finally be addressed at European level. We need to find a way to enable these people to vote in European elections. There is no democracy which is not inclusive. If it is not inclusive, it is not a democracy.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr Chairman!Ladies and gentlemen,The referendum in Ireland paved the way for the repeal of the right to defend the lives of the weakest in this country's legislation, but unfortunately the European Union was not neutral in this decision.Commissioner Vestager officially endorsed the abortion side and, what is more, despite the appeals to the European Commission to clearly distance itself from this act on the part of Commissioner Vestager, which contradicted official declarations repeatedly stated that abortion is not a subject of European Union policy, the Commissioner's actionsmet with no disapproval.Ladies and gentlemen,We will not implement real solidarity in the European Union if the officially proclaimed principle that the European Union respects the legislation of states that protects life is not officially confirmed and actually implemented.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, the EU’s General Affairs Council decided last week that Albania and Northern Macedonia cannot start association negotiations but it will, maybe, open them in June next year. Both countries have fulfilled their conditions. Northern Macedonia and Greece have found – after 27 years – a solution to the name issues, and Albania has made significant progress in almost all areas. Still, when these countries need our support our answer is: maybe, in the future the countries are too corrupt, well we will see. What happened when we need them? Then, suddenly, there are no problems! The same countries that were blocking the association negotiations are now suddenly talking about Albania helping them build these refugee camps that nobody wants to build. Suddenly we don’t have any problem with giving them millions of euros for building these refugee camps and everything is perfect. This is nothing more than hypocrisy. We are letting these countries down when they need us, and we use their weak position when we need them. It is shameful. Western Balkan countries have to open their negotiations right now, otherwise we will be nothing more than hypocrites.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: - Mr. President, yesterday, July 1, there were elections in Mexico. Andrés Manuel López Obrador was elected president with a large majority. As an MEP with special dedication to Mexico, I am very happy about this election, but the new president has an immense task before him: to fight against poverty, abolish corruption and end drug trafficking that, with the collusion of all levels of the State and Almost absolute impunity has caused, particularly since 2006, more than 37,000 disappeared, tortured, kidnapped and 240,000 dead. The recent Internal Security Law has only made things worse, because it has meant the total militarization of the State's struggle. The law must be repealed; The creation of a specific prosecutor's office is urgent, as well as the creation of a truth commission. And I hope that the renewal of the Global Agreement between the European Union and Mexico includes these advances in a democratic clause for the defense of human rights that is truly effective. Congratulations to the Mexicans, success and luck. My absolute solidarity.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Mr President, I’d like to start by offering my solidarity to the interpreters, without whom we couldn’t do our jobs. But, tonight, water is a highly political topic and, after all, water is life. In 2014, 1.9 million people from across the EU signed the ‘Right2Water’ European citizens’ initiative. It called for water to be recognised as a human right. This initiative resulted in a deeply disappointing but hardly surprising response from the Commission. In a box-ticking exercise, they have tried to slip a small reference to access to water into the recast of the Drinking Water Directive, but immediately the right-wing forces are doing their best to delete even this small reference. Ireland’s own Environment Minister was not found wanting either: at last week’s European Environment Council meeting, in a bizarre intervention, he said he supports the right to water in principle but doesn’t wanted it included in EU directives. Does he not understand that this is the central demand of the Right2Water citizens’ initiative? People specifically want an EU reference because it is the very same EU Commission pushing the privatisation agenda. The Irish Right2Water movement is watching you, Minister Naughten and they won’t forget this betrayal.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: - Thank you very much, Mr President. I would like to thank you for speaking in the last plenary on the attacks on the Roma in Ukraine, and I thank the Commission very much for responding to this last week, and perhaps an agreement between Parliament and the Commission may begin tomorrow that the the case can be thoroughly investigated and the instigators and perpetrators brought to justice. All the more so since he was already the deadly victim of these attacks last week. It is unacceptable for anti-Gypsyism to claim lives! I believe that this can be ended, both in the EU and outside the EU, by creating the economic integration of the Roma. The precondition for this, the precondition for ending anti-Gypsyism, is economic integration. This would mean a lot of tax revenue for Europe and much less expenditure. I would like to thank Bulgaria for allowing the European Roma strategy to develop further this semester, and I would like to ask the Austrian Presidency to put the Roma strategy on their agenda and adopt it after 2020, investing in education, early childhood education and factories. emphasis. Thank you very much!

name: Wajid KHAN
text: – Mr President, Islamophobic travel bans, withdrawing from the UN Human Rights Council and now industrial-scale family separations and detentions. The US Trump administration is graduating from post-truth to post-human rights. In the so-called ‘land of the free’ almost 2 000 children have been forcibly removed from their parents in just six weeks. Up to 1 500 children are detained in a warehouse. Authorities plan to hold hundreds more in tents on exposed land where temperatures reach 40 degrees celsius. These are children, and this is happening in a country that presents itself as a bastion of freedom. We must not shy away from our duty to champion human rights and to condemn abuses wherever they occur. In this Chamber we are used to calling out human rights abuses in war-torn countries and in dictatorships. Now we condemn the human rights situation in the United States of America. I hope that we will unite in telling the United States administration that these abuses must end and a plan must be put in place to keep migrant families together.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, I convey to you the cry of agony and protest of the inhabitants of the Aegean islands, who can not stand other refugees and illegal immigrants. Lesvos, Chios, Samos, Leros, Kos, at the moment, are flooded with thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants amounting to 17,293. At the same time, at least 40,000 are in the rest of Greece and, instead of having the relocation process in place, Germany has taken only 1/3 of what it had to do with the relocation process and, as if that were not enough, Dublin III and At the same time, Mrs Merkel, signed by Tsipras, decides to send several refugees back to Greece, based on a bilateral agreement. It is an unacceptable process, it will not be accepted. We support the protest of the residents of Samos, in the village of Mytilini, who are protesting against this situation.

name: Yana TOOM
text: – Mr President, on 13 June, the majority of this Chamber supported the report on cybersecurity. The report stated that European institutions should not use software which is confirmed to be malicious, such as software from Kaspersky Lab. The statement was ill-founded. There is no proof that software from Kaspersky Lab is malicious. The Commission earlier stated that there was no information about threats associated with Kaspersky anti-virus programmes. Kaspersky participated together with Europol in the investigation of complex cybercrimes, where hundreds of millions of euros were at stake.  In addition, together with Europol, the Dutch police and others they founded the No More Ransom project, which helped thousands of victims of ransomware to get their encrypted data back without having to pay criminals. After the adoption of the report, Kaspersky Lab felt forced to stop the cooperation with Europol and the No More Ransom initiative. The report was supposed to strengthen cyber—defence in the EU, but unfortunately, it has done the exact opposite. I would say this was a careless and irresponsible decision.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I would like to dwell on cohesion policy at my minute.Unfortunately, it is to be relatively substantially weakened in the following period, by at least 10% of its resources.Cohesion policy is really key to Europe's future, it eliminates disadvantages, builds on cohesion, helps the development of weaker regions.Without cohesion policy, many regions would be fundamentally weakened.The scissors between them would develop far more than they do today.For me, cohesion policy is an expression of Europeanism and solidarity.I consider the weakening of the influence and nature of cohesion policy to be extremely dangerous for our future.I would like to discuss what cohesion policy we want, what our citizens want, but I do not think that it is possible to weaken cohesion policy without affecting our future.

name: Răzvan POPA
text: - Mr President, the right to free speech and the right to political choice and association are some of the main values ​​of the democratic world, and therefore of the European Union. In recent years, there has been a resurgence of extremist and intolerant discourse and behavior. It manifests itself in various forms, including through aggressive campaigns against those with other options or even through violent actions. Unfortunately, we are beginning to see more and more such manifestations of intolerance. Various groups, sometimes encouraged at the political level, question, through their actions and messages, the very foundations of democracy, which are the free consent vote and the right of everyone to have their own choice. Recently, I myself was the victim of an act of aggression coming from the supporters of a political party in Romania. I believe that we in the European Parliament must sanction extremist slippages, wherever they occur, and that is why I call for tolerance, respect for political opinions, debate and openness. These are the defining elements of democratic dialogue. It is our obligation, as politicians attached to democratic values, to convey that the main instrument through which democracy is exercised is the free vote and that nothing excuses acts of intolerance and violence.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are talking again about the damage caused by Chancellor Merkel's irresponsible and unreasonable policies. I reiterate my position, which you have been hearing for 4 years now, a hard line, stopping illegal movement, fighting traffickers. That is why we need trained police officers, and that is why we need the establishment of uniform minimum standards for police officers in the European Union. Regardless of the country of the European Union, the European citizen must be guaranteed the same level of security and personal protection, as well as the same quality of services and assistance provided by police officers when necessary. Every European citizen must feel equally protected and have an equally good connection with their police services. That is why the European Parliament and the Union must immediately start adopting uniform minimum standards for the equipment, gear and training of police officers. The European Parliament must do so, drawing on the findings and analysis of the European Police Union, a 15-union organization that has been investigating and documenting discrepancies between Europe's various police forces over their uniforms, equipment and training for the past three years. These conclusions and analyzes were presented by the Bulgarian participants in the trade union, the trade union federation of the employees in the Ministry of Interior and I think that they definitely deserve your attention. I hope that the Austrian Presidency will address these issues.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: - Thank you very much! Dear Mr. PRESIDENT! Ukraine has opted for European integration since 2014, which is why the EU supports it through a number of instruments: visa waivers, association and free trade agreements, financially. Under the Association Agreement, Ukraine is obliged to guarantee the fundamental human and minority rights and security of the people living on its territory. We must not turn a blind eye to the recent increase in extremist manifestations against national and ethnic minorities. In addition to the restrictions on power, ultranationalist organizations have emerged whose activities are dangerous for minorities. A living example of this is the bombing of the headquarters of a Hungarian advocacy organization in Transcarpathia, or the murder of Roma last week. Members of extremist organizations have carried out 6 pogroms against Roma in the last two months. The latest attack killed a 24-year-old man, injuring several others, including a child. I thank President Tajani for commemorating this case at the beginning of the sitting. Ukraine seems to be undergoing reforms, but the minorities in the country are in an increasingly difficult situation. Their constitutional rights are constantly narrowing and they face discrimination on a daily basis. I therefore call on the leaders of the European Union to follow developments and call on the Ukrainian authorities to ensure the peaceful coexistence of their citizens. Thanks!

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the foundations of our democratic societies are universal suffrage and the rule of law, especially the Constitution and the decisions of the Constitutional Court. I draw your attention to the fact that, in my country, in Romania, with the help of some European political forces, they try to ignore both the result of the vote and the Constitution. Today marks 25 days since the Constitutional Court ruled that the President of Romania, Klaus Iohannis, must issue a decree dismissing the head of DNA, Laura Codruța Kövesi, and he refuses. It is inadmissible for the President of a Member State of the European Union not to comply with the decision of the highest court in the State. Perhaps it would be normal for the members of the EPP, a political group of which Klaus Iohannis is a member, to explain that, in a genuine democracy, politics and politics go only up to the Constitution and the decisions of the Constitutional Court. Otherwise, democracy turns into anarchy.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, on 23 June nearly half a million people from all walks of life filled the streets of London to demand a people’s vote on the final Brexit deal. I joined with Women for Europe, a campaigning group who recognise that our rights will not be best protected by being outside the EU and that the cost of Brexit will impact on women much more than men, as we women always pay the price of increased household costs and we bear the burden of caring for our families in times of crisis. And, believe me, Brexit will usher in a new era of austerity for the many, not the few. I marched with young people who feel that their future has been stolen from them. They are furious, and we should heed them as they will not treat Brexiteers kindly at the next elections. I also marched with disabled people and military veterans, including a 96-year-old war veteran who fought against the fascism of the 1930s and 40s. The EU is a precious peace project – not simply a market – and we destroy it at our peril. All the more reason to stop Brexit.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The examination on this point is over.
